revision.text:
==MTE 203==
==MTE 204==
==MTE 220==
==MTE 241==
Questions Expected to Appear: The prof said that there will be four questions on the exam, closely following the format of previous year's exams. They will cover the following topics:
* 1. RTOS, project based question. This will probably involve making a modification to the existing project base. * 2. Unix fork operation. * 3. Disk I/O, I/O transfer. * 4. A mash-up of smaller questions, for example, something about processes/threads.
Two midterms with solutions are available on the EngSoc website. [edit] Review Guideline
Review Advice from the prof:
Review course overheads ch 1-3, RTOS, ch 4-6.
Review related chapters in the course text (ch 1-6) and the "Example Design of a Non-Preemptive Real-Time Kernel" document (RTOS).
Review Home Problems Set A and their solutions.
Review Example Midterm problems and their solutions.
[edit] Room Allocation
Room assignment, by the first letter of last name:
DWE 1502, letters A-C
DWE 1515, letters D-K
DWE 2536, letters L-S
DWE 3517, letters T-Z
==SYDE 252==
===Midterm 1===
===Midterm 2===

==MTE 204==
==MTE 220==

Lecture Topics: *Instability in Numerical Solutions *Approximation and Error (Absolute / Relative) *Number Base Conversion (i.e. Decimal -> Binary) *Computer Numerical Representations *Rounding & Computation Errors *Non-Linear Equations '''Finding Roots''' *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Incremental_Search_Method|Incremental Search]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Bisection_Method|Bisection Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Newton-Raphson_Method|Newton-Raphson Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Secant_Method|Secant Method]] '''Solving Equations''' *Simultaneous Linear Equations *Gaussian Elimination Method *Gauss-Jordan Elimination Method *Lower/Upper Decomposition Method *Jacob and Gauss-Seidel Iteration Methods
====Room Allocation====
==[[MTE 241]]==
Two midterms with solutions are available on the EngSoc website.
====Questions Expected to Appear====
The prof said that there will be four questions on the exam, closely following the format of previous year's exams. They will cover the following topics:
* 1. RTOS, project based question. This will probably involve making a modification to the existing project base. * 2. Unix fork operation. * 3. Disk I/O, I/O transfer. * 4. A mash-up of smaller questions, for example, something about processes/threads.
====Review Resources====
Review Advice from the prof:
:Review course overheads ch 1-3, RTOS, ch 4-6.
:Review related chapters in the course text (ch 1-6) and the "Example Design of a Non-Preemptive Real-Time Kernel" document (RTOS).
:Review Home Problems Set A and their solutions.
:Review Example Midterm problems and their solutions.

==[[MTE 241]]== Monday October 25, 2010 (17:45 : 90mins)
Two midterms with solutions are available on the EngSoc website.
====Questions Expected to Appear====
The prof said that there will be four questions on the exam, closely following the format of previous year's exams. They will cover the following topics:
* 1. RTOS, project based question. This will probably involve making a modification to the existing project base. * 2. Unix fork operation. * 3. Disk I/O, I/O transfer. * 4. A mash-up of smaller questions, for example, something about processes/threads.
====Review Resources====
Review Advice from the prof:
:Review course overheads ch 1-3, RTOS, ch 4-6.
:Review related chapters in the course text (ch 1-6) and the "Example Design of a Non-Preemptive Real-Time Kernel" document (RTOS).
:Review Home Problems Set A and their solutions.
:Review Example Midterm problems and their solutions.

'''Vectors and 3D Geometry''' *Equations of Lines and Planes (Trim 11.5) *Shortest Distance (Trim 11.6) **Point to Line **Point to Plane **Line to Line *Curves and Surfaces (Trim 11.2) *Vector Functions (Trim 11.9 - Trim 11.13) '''Multi-Variable Calculus''' *Multi-Variable Functions *Partial Derivatives **Laplace Equation **Wave Equation *Chain Rule for Partial Derivatives (Trim 12.6) *Implicit Differentiation (Trim 12.7) *Directional Derivatives (Trim 12.8) *Gradients (Trim 12.4)
====Review Guideline====
Allowed Materials: * Mathematical Handbook of Formulae and Tables (NO ANNOTATIONS!!) * UW Math Approved Calculator [https://fortuna.uwaterloo.ca/cgi-bin/cgiwrap/rsic/shop/special/calculators.html] * Stationary
'''No''' Cheat Sheet Allowed
====Room Allocation====
You may choose the room you will write in, however each room has a limited number of papers. :DWE 2536 :DWE 2527
==[[MTE 204]]== Wednesday October 27, 2010
==== Formula Sheet ==== :[[Media:MTE204 Midterm 2010 Crib.pdf|MTE204 Midterm Crib Sheet]]
====Questions Expected to Appear====
====Review Guideline====
Lecture Topics: *Instability in Numerical Solutions *[[Computational Error]] *Significant Digits *Number Base Conversion (i.e. Decimal -> Binary) *Rounding & Computation Errors *Non-Linear Equations '''Finding Roots''' *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Incremental_Search_Method|Incremental Search]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Bisection_Method|Bisection Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Newton-Raphson_Method|Newton-Raphson Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Secant_Method|Secant Method]] '''Solving Equations''' *Simultaneous Linear Equations (know Euclidean/Vector norms and other content from handout that was covered in class) *[[Gaussian Elimination Method]] *[[Gauss-Jordan Elimination Method]] *[[Lower/Upper Decomposition Method]] (formulas for entries will be provided) *[[Jacobi Iteration Method]] *[[Gauss-Seidel Iteration Methods]] *[[Choleski Method]] '''Curve Fitting''' *Collocation Polynomial Fit *Interpolation Using Newton’s Divided Difference Method
====Room Allocation====
Room assignment, by the first letter of last name:
:DWE 2536, letters A-L
:RCH 112, letters M-Z
==[[MTE 220]]== Friday October 29, 2010
====Formula Sheet==== [http://ece.uwaterloo.ca/~mte220/CribSheet.pdf|MTE220 Midterm Crib Sheet]
*Note that the only really useful thing on the sheet appears to be the Schmidt Trigger circuit diagrams since we have not applied any of the other concepts in assignments.
====Questions Expected to Appear====
====Review Guideline==== *Basic Circuits (Op-amp and diode circuits) **[[Operational Amplifiers|Op-Amp Circuits]] ***Inverting Amplifier ***Summer ***Non-inverting Amplifier ***Difference Amplifier ***Instrumentation Amplifier ***[[Schmitt Trigger]] (Zero & Non-zero reference, Inverting & Non-inverting) <-- Given on cheat-sheet **[[Transistors]] **[[Diodes|Diode Circuits]] ***Rectifiers (p.24 course notes) ***Peak Detector ***Clamp ***Limiters *[[Bode Plotting]]
====Room Allocation==== :DWE 2536 :DWE 3522
==[[MTE 241]]== Monday October 25, 2010 (17:45 : 90mins)
Two midterms with solutions are available on the EngSoc website.
====Questions Expected to Appear====
The prof said that there will be four questions on the exam, closely following the format of previous year's exams. They will cover the following topics:
* 1. RTOS, project based question. This will probably involve making a modification to the existing project base. * 2. Unix fork operation. * 3. Disk I/O, I/O transfer. * 4. A mash-up of smaller questions, for example, something about processes/threads.
====Review Resources====
Review Advice from the prof:
:Review course overheads ch 1-3, RTOS, ch 4-6.
:Review related chapters in the course text (ch 1-6) and the "Example Design of a Non-Preemptive Real-Time Kernel" document (RTOS).
:Review Home Problems Set A and their solutions.
:Review Example Midterm problems and their solutions.
====Room Allocation====
Room assignment, by the first letter of last name:
:DWE 1502, letters A-C
:DWE 1515, letters D-K
:DWE 2536, letters L-S
:DWE 3517, letters T-Z

revision.text: Introduction to Bode plots: See Link --> [http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:M1EKFDIwwTsJ:www.ece.utah.edu/~ee3110/bodeplot.pdf+intrductiion+to+bode+plots&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESghuOVxLQnRHofgR-7gEx3SnsMmGk-efdmKScI_kwU-mDo1tnV23XvYne7L1xPju3WxLy4D2KrmSgk5cs3wEcPGN81KU6Tuq3rJBB-mKhzEaiLaiRnMps7P8niGQQ32GG607lT7&sig=AHIEtbREoB_7EbeVeup7f0dvP5ukS3wBLw]

==Steps for Linear Plots== 1. Memorize all the basic plots and their angles. These were given in class, and are also given in the first few pages of the "Introduction to Bode Plots" PDF link. 2. Test function at T(j0) and T(j*infinity) to get end bounds. 3. Graph all basic plot parts as determined in step 1. 4. Plot final line, following the directions of the previously plotted basic parts.
==Tips== *Most lines increase/decrease with a slope of 20db/dec. If a term is to a higher power then multiply this slop by that power.
==Resources== There is some material on Bode plots in the MTE120 book, "Intro to Electric Circuits"
[http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:M1EKFDIwwTsJ:www.ece.utah.edu/~ee3110/bodeplot.pdf+intrductiion+to+bode+plots&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESghuOVxLQnRHofgR-7gEx3SnsMmGk-efdmKScI_kwU-mDo1tnV23XvYne7L1xPju3WxLy4D2KrmSgk5cs3wEcPGN81KU6Tuq3rJBB-mKhzEaiLaiRnMps7P8niGQQ32GG607lT7&sig=AHIEtbREoB_7EbeVeup7f0dvP5ukS3wBLw Introduction to Bode Plots]

Plot final line, following the directions of the previously plotted basic parts.
==Tips== *Most lines increase/decrease with a slope of 20db/dec and at ±45°/dec. If a term is to a higher power then multiply this slope by that power. *Qo Defines the family of curve that will be drawn. **Qo < 0.5: No resonant peaks, everything is linear, aka the first graphs that we did in class. (/-\) **Qo = 0.5: A graph that looks like this (^) . **Qo > 0.5: A resonant peak at Wo.
==Resources== *There is some material on Bode plots in the MTE120 book, "Intro to Electric Circuits"
*University of Utah ECE: [http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:M1EKFDIwwTsJ:www.ece.utah.edu/~ee3110/bodeplot.pdf+intrductiion+to+bode+plots&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESghuOVxLQnRHofgR-7gEx3SnsMmGk-efdmKScI_kwU-mDo1tnV23XvYne7L1xPju3WxLy4D2KrmSgk5cs3wEcPGN81KU6Tuq3rJBB-mKhzEaiLaiRnMps7P8niGQQ32GG607lT7&sig=AHIEtbREoB_7EbeVeup7f0dvP5ukS3wBLw Introduction to Bode Plots]
*'''TA's Resource for Bode Plotting''': [[Media:MTE220_BodePlotting.pdf]]
*A very good website that introduce bode plot (ideal for those who have no idea what blot plot is about): [http://www.swarthmore.edu/NatSci/echeeve1/Ref/LPSA/Bode/Bode.html Bode Plot Overview]

==Steps for Linear Plots== *1. Memorize all the basic plots and their angles. These were given in class, and are also given in the first few pages of the "Introduction to Bode Plots" PDF link. *2. Test function at T(j0) and T(j*infinity) to get end bounds. *3. Graph all basic plot parts as determined in step 1. *4. Plot final line, following the directions of the previously plotted basic parts.
==Tips== *Most lines increase/decrease with a slope of 20db/dec and at ±45°/dec. If a term is to a higher power then multiply this slope by that power. *Qo Defines the family of curve that will be drawn. **Qo < 0.5: No resonant peaks, everything is linear, aka the first graphs that we did in class. (/-\) **Qo = 0.5: A graph that looks like this (^) . **Qo > 0.5: A resonant peak at Wo.
==Resources== *There is some material on Bode plots in the MTE120 book, "Intro to Electric Circuits"
*University of Utah ECE: [http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:M1EKFDIwwTsJ:www.ece.utah.edu/~ee3110/bodeplot.pdf+intrductiion+to+bode+plots&hl=en&gl=ca&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESghuOVxLQnRHofgR-7gEx3SnsMmGk-efdmKScI_kwU-mDo1tnV23XvYne7L1xPju3WxLy4D2KrmSgk5cs3wEcPGN81KU6Tuq3rJBB-mKhzEaiLaiRnMps7P8niGQQ32GG607lT7&sig=AHIEtbREoB_7EbeVeup7f0dvP5ukS3wBLw Introduction to Bode Plots]
*'''TA's Resource for Bode Plotting''': [[Media:MTE220_BodePlotting.pdf]]
*A very good website that introduce bode plot (ideal for those who have no idea what blot plot is about): [http://www.swarthmore.edu/NatSci/echeeve1/Ref/LPSA/Bode/Bode.html Bode Plot Overview] *Basic knowledge in resonance is important!: [http://www.allaboutcircuits.com/vol_2/chpt_6/index.html Resonance]]

==Specific Volume==
==Specific Volume== ==Definition== Volume per unit mass. It is the reciprocal of density: <math> v = 1/\rho </math>

revision.comment: Created page with "==Overview== Choleski Method is useful for solving '''symmetric, positive''' matrices. ==Method== The defining equation of this method is: <math>[A]=[U]^{T}[U]</math> Where U..."
revision.text:
==Overview== Choleski Method is useful for solving '''symmetric, positive''' matrices.
==Method== The defining equation of this method is:
<math>[A]=[U]^{T}[U]</math>
Where U is an upper-triangular matrix including the diagonal. The elements of U are given by certain equations (available on the MTE 204 cheat-sheet).

revision.comment: Created page with "== Absolute Error == == Relative Error =="
revision.text:
== Absolute Error ==
== Relative Error ==

== Absolute Error == An approximation of a number (<math>\tilde x</math>) is made up of an absolute value (x) and absolute error (<math>E_{x}</math>) such that:
<math>x = \tilde x + E_{x}</math>
== Relative Error ==

== Absolute Error == An approximation of a number (<math>\tilde x</math>) is made up of an absolute value (x) and absolute error (<math>E_{x}</math>) such that:
<math>x = \tilde x + E_{x}</math>
== Relative Error ==
The Relative Error is defined as:

== Absolute Error == An approximation of a number (<math>\tilde x</math>) is made up of an absolute value (x) and absolute error (<math>E_{x}</math>) such that:
<math>x = \tilde x + E_{x}</math>
== Relative Error ==
The Relative Error is defined as:
<math>R_{x} = {x - \tilde x \over x}</math>

revision.comment: Created page with "==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252 ==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252 ===Properties of DT Convolution..."
revision.text:
==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math>

==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math> <math>x[n - M] * \delta[n] = x[n - M]</math>

==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
====width property=====
The width of the convolution of two signals is the sum of the width of the two signals. The width of a DT signal is one less than the length of the signal. The length of a signal is the number of elements in the signal. For example if a signal has three "blips", then it has a length of three, and a width of two.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math> <math>x[n - M] * \delta[n] = x[n - M]</math>

==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
The convolution of two functions is solved using the following equation: <math>x[n] * g[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]g[n-m]</math>
The result is often a geometric series. The series can be solved using this equation: <math>\sum_{k=m}^n ar^k=\frac{a(r^m-r^{n+1})}{1-r}.</math>
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
====width property=====
The width of the convolution of two signals is the sum of the width of the two signals. The width of a DT signal is one less than the length of the signal. The length of a signal is the number of elements in the signal. For example if a signal has three "blips", then it has a length of three, and a width of two.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math> <math>x[n - M] * \delta[n] = x[n - M]</math>

==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
The convolution of two functions is solved using the following equation: <math>x[n] * g[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]g[n-m]</math>
The result is often a geometric series. The series can be solved using this equation: <math>\sum_{k=m}^n ar^k=\frac{a(r^m-r^{n+1})}{1-r}.</math>
===Graphical Procedure for DT Convolution=== *1. Plot x[n] and g[n] as functions of m. *2. Flip g about the y axis to obtain g[-m] *3. Start shifting g[-m] by n units to obtain f[n-m] *4. Multiply each blip from x[m] with the corresponding blips from g[n-m]. Then sum all the products. This is the value of c[n] *5. Plot c[n] and repeat from step 3.
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
====width property=====
The width of the convolution of two signals is the sum of the width of the two signals. The width of a DT signal is one less than the length of the signal. The length of a signal is the number of elements in the signal. For example if a signal has three "blips", then it has a length of three, and a width of two.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math> <math>x[n - M] * \delta[n] = x[n - M]</math>

==Continuous Time Convolution== This topic was seen in MTE 201 and SYDE 252
==Discrete Time Convolution== This concept was discussed in SYDE 252
The convolution of two functions is solved using the following equation: <math>x[n] * g[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]g[n-m]</math>
The result is often a geometric series. The series can be solved using this equation: <math>\sum_{k=m}^n ar^k=\frac{a(r^m-r^{n+1})}{1-r}.</math>
===Graphical Procedure for DT Convolution=== # Plot x[n] and g[n] as functions of m. # Flip g about the y axis to obtain g[-m] # Start shifting g[-m] by n units to obtain f[n-m] # Multiply each blip from x[m] with the corresponding blips from g[n-m]. Then sum all the products. This is the value of c[n] # Plot c[n] and repeat from step 3.
===Properties of DT Convolution===
Commutative, distributive, associative, shifting property and width property. Needs examples.
====width property=====
The width of the convolution of two signals is the sum of the width of the two signals. The width of a DT signal is one less than the length of the signal. The length of a signal is the number of elements in the signal. For example if a signal has three "blips", then it has a length of three, and a width of two.
===DT Convolution with an Impulse===
A function in DT convolved with the unit impulse function equals itself. eg:
<math>x[n] * \delta[n] = x[n]</math> <math>x[n - M] * \delta[n] = x[n - M]</math>

revision.comment: Created page with " == Overview == Cramer's Rule is an algorithm for solving a set of linear equations using Matrices. The examples given here use a 3*3 matrix since it is most common for us to us..."
revision.text:
== Overview ==
Cramer's Rule is an algorithm for solving a set of linear equations using Matrices. The examples given here use a 3*3 matrix since it is most common for us to use this based this size of a matrix.
== Formula ==
The rules for 3×3 are similar. Given <math>\left\{\begin{matrix}ax + by + cz&= {\color{red}j}\\dx + ey + fz&= {\color{red}k}\\gx + hy + iz&= {\color{red}l}\end{matrix}\right.</math> which in matrix format is :<math>\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} {\color{red}j} \\ {\color{red}k} \\ {\color{red}l} \end{bmatrix}</math> the values of ''x'', ''y'' and ''z'' can be found as follows:
:<math>x = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} {\color{red}j} & b & c \\ {\color{red}k} & e & f \\ {\color{red}l} & h & i \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} }, \quad y = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} a & {\color{red}j} & c \\ d & {\color{red}k} & f \\ g & {\color{red}l} & i \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} },\text{ and }z = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & {\color{red}j} \\ d & e & {\color{red}k} \\ g & h & {\color{red}l} \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} }.</math>
== Explanation ==

== Overview ==
Cramer's Rule is an algorithm for solving a set of linear equations using Matrices. The examples given here use a 3*3 matrix since it is most common for us to use this based this size of a matrix.
== Formula ==
Given <math>\left\{\begin{matrix}ax + by + cz&= {\color{red}j}\\dx + ey + fz&= {\color{red}k}\\gx + hy + iz&= {\color{red}l}\end{matrix}\right.</math> which in matrix format is :<math>\begin{bmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} {\color{red}j} \\ {\color{red}k} \\ {\color{red}l} \end{bmatrix}</math> the values of ''x'', ''y'' and ''z'' can be found as follows:
:<math>x = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} {\color{red}j} & b & c \\ {\color{red}k} & e & f \\ {\color{red}l} & h & i \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} }, \quad y = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} a & {\color{red}j} & c \\ d & {\color{red}k} & f \\ g & {\color{red}l} & i \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} },\text{ and }z = \frac { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & {\color{red}j} \\ d & e & {\color{red}k} \\ g & h & {\color{red}l} \end{vmatrix} } { \begin{vmatrix} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{vmatrix} }.</math>
== Explanation ==

revision.comment: Created page with "Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations. A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satits..."
revision.text:
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
==Relative Maxima / Minima==
====Find Critical Points==== To find a maximum or minimum of an equation, the points of interest are those in which the gradient of the function is equal to zero. To find these points solve for:
:<math>\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2} = 0 \qquad \frac{d^2 f}{dy^2} = 0</math>
and substitue these equations into one another.
====Find Max/Min==== Once the critical points have been found, you must determine whether each is a max or a min. To do this use the second derivative test:
:<math>A=f_{xx}(a,b)</math>
:<math>B=f_{yy}(a,b) \qquad \qquad D=A*C - B^{2}</math>
:<math>C=f_{xy}(a,b)</math>
if: ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A < 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Max</math> ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A > 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Min</math>

Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
==Relative Maxima / Minima==
====Find Critical Points==== To find a maximum or minimum of an equation, the points of interest are those in which the gradient of the function is equal to zero. To find these points solve for:
:<math>\frac{d^2 f}{dx^2} = 0 \qquad \frac{d^2 f}{dy^2} = 0</math>
and substitue these equations into one another.
====Find Max/Min==== Once the critical points have been found, you must determine whether each is a max or a min. To do this use the second derivative test:
:<math>A=f_{xx}(a,b)</math>
:<math>B=f_{yy}(a,b) \qquad \qquad D=A*C - B^{2}</math>
:<math>C=f_{xy}(a,b)</math>
if: ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A < 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Max</math> ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A > 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Min</math>
==Absolute Maxima / Minima==
====Find Relative Maxima / Minima==== To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
====Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)==== >>TO DO<<
====Find Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum====
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps.

and substitue these equations into one another.
====Find Max/Min==== Once the critical points have been found, you must determine whether each is a max or a min. To do this use the second derivative test:
:<math>A=f_{xx}(a,b)</math>
:<math>B=f_{yy}(a,b) \qquad \qquad D=A*C - B^{2}</math>
:<math>C=f_{xy}(a,b)</math>
if: ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A < 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Max</math> ::<math>D > 0 \quad and \quad A > 0 \quad ==> \quad Relative Min</math>
==Absolute Maxima / Minima==
====Find Relative Maxima / Minima==== To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
====Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)==== [[Twiki Todo]]
====Find Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum====
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps.

On midterm?

revision.text: A discrete system is a sequence of numbers. It differs from a continuous time system in that an output value is ''not'' defined at for every time ''t'', but rather only for specific values of time.

A discrete system is a sequence of numbers. It differs from a continuous time system in that an output value is ''not'' defined at for every time ''t'', but rather only for specific values of time.
==Strength of a Signal==
The '''energy''' of a signal is defined as: <math>E_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^(\infty} \abs{x[n]}^2 < \infty </math>

A discrete system is a sequence of numbers. It differs from a continuous time system in that an output value is ''not'' defined at for every time ''t'', but rather only for specific values of time.
==Strength of a Signal==
The '''energy''' of a signal is defined as: <math>E_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \abs{x[n]}^2 < \infty </math>
The '''Power''' of a signal is defined as: <math>P_x = {1 \over N} \sum_0^{N-1} \abs {x[n]}^2</math>. This only applies to periodic signals.
==Signal Operations==
Time Shifting: <math>x[n] \to x[n - M]</math>

A discrete system is a sequence of numbers. It differs from a continuous time system in that an output value is ''not'' defined at for every time ''t'', but rather only for specific values of time.
==Strength of a Signal==
The '''energy''' of a signal is defined as: <math>E_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \abs{x[n]}^2 < \infty </math>
The '''Power''' of a signal is defined as: <math>P_x = {1 \over N} \sum_0^{N-1} \abs {x[n]}^2</math>. This only applies to periodic signals.
==Signal Operations==
Time Shifting: <math>x[n] \to x[n - M]</math>
Time Reversal: <math>x[n] \to x[-n]</math>
Decimation: <math>x[n] \to x[Mn]</math> *Note that information can be lost when something is decimated (hence the name). Example on p. 184 of textbook (Intl')

==Strength of a Signal==
The '''energy''' of a signal is defined as: <math>E_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \abs{x[n]}^2 < \infty </math>
The '''Power''' of a signal is defined as: <math>P_x = {1 \over N} \sum_0^{N-1} \abs {x[n]}^2</math>. This only applies to periodic signals.
==Signal Operations==
Time Shifting: <math>x[n] \to x[n - M]</math>
Time Reversal: <math>x[n] \to x[-n]</math>
Decimation: <math>x[n] \to x[Mn]</math> *Note that information can be lost when something is decimated (hence the name). Example on p. 184 of textbook (Intl')
==Special Functions in DT==
===Unit Step Function=== <math>u[n] = {1, n \leq 0 \brace 0, n \geq 0}</math>
===Unit Impulse Function===
<math>\delta[n] = {1, n = 0 \brace 0, n \neq 0}</math>
==The Difference Equation== incomplete...
Advanced form vs delayed form...
===Solving Difference Equations=== ====Zero-Input Response==== *1.Set the input (x[n]) to 0. Therefore: <math>Q[E]y_0[n] = 0</math> *2.Create the characteristic equation of the system, <math>Q[\lambda] = 0</math> *3.Solve the characteristic equation, the characteristic roots are <math>\gamma^n</math>'s *4.Based on what type of roots exist, create the characteristic modes: **'''Real Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Repeated Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Complex Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma^n + c_2(\gamma*)^n = c|\gamma|^ncos(\beta n + \theta)</math>

===Time Invariant=== incomplete...
===Causal/Non-Causal=== Same as in Continuous Time
===Memory/Memoryless=== Same as in continuous time
==Convolution== Discrete time convolution is discussed on the [[Convolution]] page.
==Connected Systems== Connected systems behave differently in DT then in CT.
===Parallel Systems=== For two systems in parallel, add their effects together to obtain the total effect. ie: <math>s_1 + s_2 = S_T</math>
===Series Systems=== For multiple systems in series,
<math>{\buildrel x[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_1] {\buildrel y_1[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_2] {\buildrel y[n] \over \longrightarrow} </math>
Then <math> y = x[n] * ( h_1[n] * h_2[n] )</math> where h[n] is the unit impulse response of the respective system.

==The Difference Equation== incomplete...
Advanced form vs delayed form...
===Solving Difference Equations=== ====Zero-Input Response==== *1.Set the input (x[n]) to 0. Replace time-shifts with E. (eg: y[n+2] = E^2y[n]) Therefore: <math>Q[E]y_0[n] = 0</math> *2.Create the characteristic equation of the system, <math>Q[\lambda] = 0</math> *3.Solve the characteristic equation, the characteristic roots are <math>\gamma^n</math>'s *4.Based on what type of roots exist, create the characteristic modes: **'''Real Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Repeated Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2n\gamma_1^n + ... + c_nn^n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Complex Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma^n + c_2(\gamma*)^n = c|\gamma|^ncos(\beta n + \theta)</math>
===Unit Impulse Response=== Solve the equation <math>Q[E]y[n] = P[E]x[n]</math> for the input<math>\delta [n]</math> *1.Set <math>x[n]=\delta[n]</math> *2.Set all initial conditions to zero.
i.e.: solve this equation setting all initial conditions to zero. <math>Q[E]h[n] = P[E]\delta[n]</math>
==Zero State Response== <math>y_{zsr} = x[n]*h[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]h[n-m]</math>

<math>{\buildrel x[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_1] {\buildrel y_1[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_2] {\buildrel y[n] \over \longrightarrow} </math>
Then <math> y = x[n] * ( h_1[n] * h_2[n] )</math> where h[n] is the unit impulse response of the respective system.
==Stability==
The stability of a DTS... was it even discussed in class???

A discrete system is a sequence of numbers. It differs from a continuous time system in that an output value is ''not'' defined at for every time ''t'', but rather only for specific values of time.
==Strength of a Signal==
The '''energy''' of a signal is defined as: <math>E_x = \sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty} \abs{x[n]}^2 < \infty </math>
The '''Power''' of a signal is defined as: <math>P_x = {1 \over N} \sum_0^{N-1} \abs {x[n]}^2</math>. This only applies to periodic signals.
==Signal Operations==
Time Shifting: <math>x[n] \to x[n - M]</math>
Time Reversal: <math>x[n] \to x[-n]</math>
Decimation: <math>x[n] \to x[Mn]</math> *Note that information can be lost when something is decimated (hence the name). Example on p. 184 of textbook (Intl')
==Special Functions in DT==
===Unit Step Function=== <math>u[n] = {1, n \leq 0 \brace 0, n \geq 0}</math>
===Unit Impulse Function===
<math>\delta[n] = {1, n = 0 \brace 0, n \neq 0}</math>
==The Difference Equation== incomplete...
Advanced form vs delayed form...
===Solving Difference Equations=== ====Zero-Input Response==== *1.Set the input (x[n]) to 0. Replace time-shifts with E. (eg: y[n+2] = E^2y[n]) Therefore: <math>Q[E]y_0[n] = 0</math> *2.Create the characteristic equation of the system, <math>Q[\lambda] = 0</math> *3.Solve the characteristic equation, the characteristic roots are <math>\gamma^n</math>'s *4.Based on what type of roots exist, create the characteristic modes: **'''Real Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Repeated Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2n\gamma_1^n + ... + c_nn^n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Complex Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma^n + c_2(\gamma*)^n = c|\gamma|^ncos(\beta n + \theta)</math>
===Unit Impulse Response=== Solve the equation <math>Q[E]y[n] = P[E]x[n]</math> for the input<math>\delta [n]</math> *1.Set <math>x[n]=\delta[n]</math> *2.Set all initial conditions to zero.
i.e.: solve this equation setting all initial conditions to zero. <math>Q[E]h[n] = P[E]\delta[n]</math>
===Zero State Response=== <math>y_{zsr} = x[n]*h[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]h[n-m]</math>
===Classical Method of Solving Difference Equations=== The classical method says that the total response of a system is equal to the natural response of the system (all characteristic modes) plus the force response of the system (the remaining non-characteristic mode terms).
<math>Total Response = y_c[n] + y-\phi[n]</math>
==Classification of Discrete Time Systems==
===Linear/Non-linear=== incomplete...
===Time Invariant=== incomplete...
===Causal/Non-Causal=== Same as in Continuous Time
===Memory/Memoryless=== Same as in continuous time
==Convolution== Discrete time convolution is discussed on the [[Convolution]] page.
==Connected Systems== Connected systems behave differently in DT then in CT.
===Parallel Systems=== For two systems in parallel, add their effects together to obtain the total effect. ie: <math>s_1 + s_2 = S_T</math>
===Series Systems=== For multiple systems in series,
<math>{\buildrel x[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_1] {\buildrel y_1[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_2] {\buildrel y[n] \over \longrightarrow} </math>
Then <math> y = x[n] * ( h_1[n] * h_2[n] )</math> where h[n] is the unit impulse response of the respective system.
==Stability==
The stability of a DTS... was it even discussed in class???

===Linear/Non-linear=== incomplete...
===Time Invariant=== incomplete...

===Memory/Memoryless=== Same as in continuous time
==Convolution== Discrete time convolution is discussed on the [[Convolution]] page.

==Stability==
Imagine a unit circle on the Real/Imaginary cartesian plot. If both poles are inside this circle, the system is stable. If they are on the circle's perimeter, the system is marginally stable. If the poles lie outside the circle, the system is unstable.

(eg: y[n+2] = E^2y[n]) Therefore: <math>Q[E]y_0[n] = 0</math> *2.Create the characteristic equation of the system, <math>Q[\lambda] = 0</math> *3.Solve the characteristic equation, the characteristic roots are <math>\gamma^n</math>'s *4.Based on what type of roots exist, create the characteristic modes: **'''Real Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Repeated Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2n\gamma_1^n + ... + c_nn^n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Complex Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma^n + c_2(\gamma*)^n = c|\gamma|^ncos(\beta n + \theta)</math>

<math>\delta[n] = {1, n = 0 \brace 0, n \neq 0}</math>
==The Difference Equation==
===Solving Difference Equations=== ====Zero-Input Response==== *1.Set the input (x[n]) to 0. Replace time-shifts with E. (eg: y[n+2] = E^2y[n]) Therefore: <math>Q[E]y_0[n] = 0</math> *2.Create the characteristic equation of the system, <math>Q[\lambda] = 0</math> *3.Solve the characteristic equation, the characteristic roots are <math>\gamma^n</math>'s *4.Based on what type of roots exist, create the characteristic modes: **'''Real Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2\gamma_2^n + ... + c_n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Repeated Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma_1^n + c_2n\gamma_1^n + ... + c_nn^n\gamma_n^n</math> **'''Complex Roots''': <math>y_0[n] = c_1\gamma^n + c_2(\gamma*)^n = c|\gamma|^ncos(\beta n + \theta)</math>
===Unit Impulse Response=== Solve the equation <math>Q[E]y[n] = P[E]x[n]</math> for the input<math>\delta [n]</math> *1.Set <math>x[n]=\delta[n]</math> *2.Set all initial conditions to zero.
i.e.: solve this equation setting all initial conditions to zero. <math>Q[E]h[n] = P[E]\delta[n]</math>
====Closed Form solution to find H[n]==== <math>h[n]=A_0\delta[n] + y_c[n]u[n]</math>, where <math>A_0 </math>= <math>b_N\over a_N</math>
===Zero State Response=== <math>y_{zsr} = x[n]*h[n] = \sum_{m=-\infty}^{\infty}x[m]h[n-m]</math>
===Classical Method of Solving Difference Equations=== The classical method says that the total response of a system is equal to the natural response of the system (all characteristic modes) plus the force response of the system (the remaining non-characteristic mode terms).
<math>Total Response = y_c[n] + y-\phi[n]</math>
==Classification of Discrete Time Systems==
===Linear/Non-linear=== incomplete...
===Time Invariant=== incomplete...
===Causal/Non-Causal=== Same as in Continuous Time
===Memory/Memoryless=== Same as in continuous time
==Convolution== Discrete time convolution is discussed on the [[Convolution]] page.
==Connected Systems== Connected systems behave differently in DT then in CT.
===Parallel Systems=== For two systems in parallel, add their effects together to obtain the total effect. ie: <math>s_1 + s_2 = S_T</math>
===Series Systems=== For multiple systems in series,
<math>{\buildrel x[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_1] {\buildrel y_1[n] \over \longrightarrow} [S_2] {\buildrel y[n] \over \longrightarrow} </math>
Then <math> y = x[n] * ( h_1[n] * h_2[n] )</math> where h[n] is the unit impulse response of the respective system.
==Stability==
Imagine a unit circle on the Real/Imaginary cartesian plot. If both poles are inside this circle, the system is stable. If they are on the circle's perimeter, the system is marginally stable. If the poles lie outside the circle, the system is unstable.
The official rules are: *1. Asymptotically stable iff ''all'' characteristic roots are inside the unit circle. They may be repeated, simple or complex. *2. Unstable iff at least one root is outside the unit circle or there are repeated roots on the unit circle. *3. Marginally stable if some roots are on the unit circle, and no roots are repeated.

==Introduction to Thermodynamics & Heat Transfer== Macroscopic approach to energy analysis. Energy transfer as work and heat, and the First Law of thermodynamics. Properties and states of simple substances. Control-mass and control-volume analyses. The essence of entropy, and the Second Law of thermodynamics. The Carnot cycle and its implications for practical cyclic devices. Introduction to heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation. Basic formulation and solution of steady and transient problems. Issues relevent to the cooling of electrical devices.
==Study Help/ECE 309 by topic==

This page exists to provide Tron students with a way to gage their position relative to the rest of the class, and hopefully debunk the low-average rumours that often arise just after exam time. ''Why do the teacher's assignment problems not match the problems in my textbook?''
If you purchased your textbook online, chances are that you have an international version of the textbook. Question numbers often differ between this book and the Canadian version of the book. A mapping has been started for the SYDE 252 course's book which can be found by visiting the course' page ([[SYDE 252]]).

== Textbooks ==
''Why do the teacher's assignment problems not match the problems in my textbook?''
If you purchased your textbook online, chances are that you have an international version of the textbook. Question numbers often differ between this book and the Canadian version of the book. revision.comment: Created page with "==Fundamental Period== The fundamental period of a function is the smallest period of that function (for example, the fundamental frequency of sin(x) is 2*pi, not 4*pi or 6*pi e..."
revision.text:
==Fundamental Period==
The fundamental period of a function is the smallest period of that function (for example, the fundamental frequency of sin(x) is 2*pi, not 4*pi or 6*pi etc...).

revision.comment: Created page with "== Overview == The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method closely resembles the [[Gauss Elimination Method]] except that on additional step performed on the Augmented Matrix. The matrix..."
revision.text: == Overview == The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method closely resembles the [[Gauss Elimination Method]] except that on additional step performed on the Augmented Matrix. The matrix is reduced to all zeros except for the diagonal (which is reduced to 1's) and the solution column which may contain any values. eg:

== Overview == The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method closely resembles the [[Gaussian Elimination Method]] except that on additional step performed on the Augmented Matrix. The matrix is reduced to all zeros except for the diagonal (which is reduced to 1's) and the solution column which may contain any values. eg:<math>\left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 0 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & val\end{array} \right)</math>

== Overview == The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method closely resembles the [[Gaussian Elimination Method]] except that on additional step performed on the Augmented Matrix. The matrix is reduced to all zeros except for the diagonal (which is reduced to 1's) and the solution column which may contain any values.
eg: <math>\left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 0 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & val\end{array} \right)</math>
== Determining the Inverse of a Matrix== The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method may be used to determine the inverse of a matrix.
The following example demonstrates this process.
<math>[C] = [[A|I]] = \left( \begin{array}{cccccc} a_{1,1} & & & 1 & 0 & 0\\ a_{1,1} & & &0 & 1 & 0\\ a_{1,1} & & &0 & 0 & 1\end{array} \right)</math>

revision.comment: /* Determining the Inverse of a Matrix */
revision.text:
== Overview == The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method closely resembles the [[Gaussian Elimination Method]] except that on additional step performed on the Augmented Matrix. The matrix is reduced to all zeros except for the diagonal (which is reduced to 1's) and the solution column which may contain any values.
eg: <math>\left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & 0 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & val\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & val\end{array} \right)</math>
== Determining the Inverse of a Matrix== The Gauss-Jordan Elimination method may be used to determine the inverse of a matrix.
The following example demonstrates this process.
<math>[C] = [[A|I]] = \left( \begin{array}{cccccc} a_{1,1} & a_{1,2} & a_{1,3} & 1 & 0 & 0\\ a_{2,1} & a_{2,2} & a_{2,3} &0 & 1 & 0\\ a_{3,1} & a_{3,2} & a_{3,3} &0 & 0 & 1\end{array} \right)</math>
The G-J Method is then applied to the matrix, and when the process is complete, I is replaced with the inverse of A (yay!).

revision.comment: Created page with "== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations. == Overview == Similar to the Jacobi Iteration Method, except ALWAYS the most recent calculated value of any variable is used. ..."
revision.text:
== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations.
== Overview == Similar to the Jacobi Iteration Method, except ALWAYS the most recent calculated value of any variable is used. This saves on memory space (if we actually had the pleasure of programming it into an embedded system).
== Method ==
== Notes ==

== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations.
== Overview == Similar to the Jacobi Iteration Method, except ALWAYS the most recent calculated value of any variable is used. This saves on memory space (if we actually had the pleasure of programming it into an embedded system).
== Method ==
== Notes == *1. Initial guess of the values <math>x_{2},x_{3},....,x_{n}</math> are required. A guess for <math>x_{1}</math> is not required. *2. Continue until ALL newly calculated values of x meet the convergence criteria (<math>\varepsilon</math>).

== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations.
== Overview == Similar to the Jacobi Iteration Method, except ALWAYS the most recent calculated value of any variable is used. This saves on memory space (if we actually had the pleasure of programming it into an embedded system).
== Method ==
== Notes == *1. Initial guess of the values <math>x_{2},x_{3},....,x_{n}</math> are required. A guess for <math>x_{1}</math> is not required. *2. Continue until ALL newly calculated values of x meet the convergence criteria (<math>\varepsilon</math>). *3. Guaranteed to converge (and converges faster) if the system of equations is diagonally dominant.

== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations.
== Overview == Similar to the [[Jacobi Iteration Method]], except ALWAYS the most recent calculated value of any variable is used. This saves on memory space (if we actually had the pleasure of programming it into an embedded system).
== Method ==
== Notes == *1. Initial guess of the values <math>x_{2},x_{3},....,x_{n}</math> are required. A guess for <math>x_{1}</math> is not required. *2. Continue until ALL newly calculated values of x meet the convergence criteria (<math>\varepsilon</math>). *3. Guaranteed to converge (and converges faster) if the system of equations is diagonally dominant.

revision.comment: Created page with "<math>\left( \begin{array}{ccc} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{array} \right)</math>"
revision.text: <math>\left( \begin{array}{ccc} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{array} \right)</math>

Remember this one from first year Algebra.
== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations
== Method ==
<math>\left( \begin{array}{ccc} a & b & c \\ d & e & f \\ g & h & i \end{array} \right)</math>

Remember this one from first year Algebra.
== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations
== Method == *1. Transform the system of equations into Augmented Matrix form. *2. Reduce the matrix to 1's across the diagonal, and 0's to the bottom-right of the diagonal (Except for the last column which can hold any values). <math>\left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & x & x & val\\ 0 & 1 & x & val\\ 0 & 0 & x & val\end{array} \right)</math> *3. Then solve the equation normally

Remember this one from first year Algebra.
== Goal == To solve a system of linear equations
== Method == *1. Transform the system of equations into Augmented Matrix form.
*2. Reduce the matrix to 1's across the diagonal, and 0's to the bottom-right of the diagonal (Except for the last column which can hold any values) using the three elementary operations (see below). <math>\left( \begin{array}{cccc} 1 & x & x & val\\ 0 & 1 & x & val\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & val\end{array} \right)</math> *3. Then solve the reduced equations normally keeping in mind that the first column represents the first variable, second column represents second variable etc...
== The Three Elementary Operations == The following operations can be used on any rows of the matrix. These operations are used to reduce the matrix to the desired form.
*1. Multiply any row by a constant. *2. Add one row to another row. *3. Rearrange the orders of the rows.

revision.text:
=Intro= Git is a version control system that is fast and flexible to use.
=Sample MTE 241 Workflow with Git=
=Git References= [http://www.gitready.com GitReady] is a blog showing nifty git tricks. Very basic to very advanced tips, with many examples. Great reference and pretty colours!
[http://gitref.org/ GitRef] Another good reference, organized on a command-by-command basis.

=Intro= Git is a version control system that is fast and flexible to use.
=Sample MTE 241 Workflow with Git=
=Git References= *[http://www.gitready.com GitReady] is a blog showing nifty git tricks. Very basic to very advanced tips, with many examples. Great reference and pretty colours! *[http://gitref.org/ GitRef] Another good reference, organized on a command-by-command basis.

=Intro= Git is a version control system that is fast and flexible to use. [www.github.com GitHub] allows you free server space for public repositories.
=Sample MTE 241 Workflow with Git=
=Git References= *[http://www.gitready.com GitReady] is a blog showing nifty git tricks. Very basic to very advanced tips, with many examples. Great reference and pretty colours! *[http://gitref.org/ GitRef] Another good reference, organized on a command-by-command basis.

=Intro= Git is a version control system that is fast and flexible to use. [www.github.com GitHub] allows you free server space for public repositories.
=Quick Git Reference Card= *'''git add''' - Add a file to your local repo. This must be done before a commit. *'''git commit''' - Commit all files to your local repo. This is like saving the files to git. *'''git push''' - Push all local changes that have been committed to your local repo to a remo repo. *'''git pull''' - Pull all changes from the remote repo to your local repo. *'''git checkout <branch>''' - Move to <branch>. This will change the files in your working directory.
=Sample MTE 241 Workflow with Git=
=Git References= *[http://www.gitready.com GitReady] is a blog showing nifty git tricks. Very basic to very advanced tips, with many examples. Great reference and pretty colours! *[http://gitref.org/ GitRef] Another good reference, organized on a command-by-command basis.

This is like saving the files to git. *'''git push''' - Push all local changes that have been committed to your local repo to a remo repo. *'''git pull''' - Pull all changes from the remote repo to your local repo. *'''git checkout <branch>''' - Move to <branch>. This will change the files in your working directory.
=Git Tips=
Tired of entering your passphrase every time you push/pull from GitHub? revision.comment: Created page with "Instability can be a result of many very different causes and can come in two general forms: *Divergence - The solution diverges at a certain point to machine overflow and eventu..."
revision.text:
Instability can be a result of many very different causes and can come in two general forms: *Divergence - The solution diverges at a certain point to machine overflow and eventually, <math>\infinity</math> *Oscillation - The solution approaches and diverges from the true solution at different values of x.
==Stability Analysis==

revision.comment: Created page with "The Jacobi Iteration Method is used to solve a system of linear equations. ==Base Equation== :<math>x_{i}^{(k+1)} = {1 \over a_{ii}}[b_{i} - \sum\limits_{j=1,j \ne i}^n a_{i,j}x..."
revision.text:
The Jacobi Iteration Method is used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Base Equation== :<math>x_{i}^{(k+1)} = {1 \over a_{ii}}[b_{i} - \sum\limits_{j=1,j \ne i}^n a_{i,j}x_{j}^{(k)}] ,i=1,2,...,n</math>
==Method== #Start with initital approximations for <math>x_{1}^{ (1)}, x_{2}^{ (2)},...,x_{n}^{ (n)}</math>. #:Assume <math>x_{i}^{ (1)}=0</math> if no better approximation #Continually iterate through <math>k</math> until stopping condition is met: #:: <math>\vert x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \vert \le \epsilon ;f\forall i = 1,2,...,n</math> #:<math>or</math> #:: <math>\vert {x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \over x_{i}^{(k)}} \vert \le \epsilon ;f\forall i = 1,2,...,n</math>

The Jacobi Iteration Method is used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Base Equation== :<math>x_{i}^{(k+1)} = {1 \over a_{ii}}[b_{i} - \sum\limits_{j=1,j \ne i}^n a_{i,j}x_{j}^{(k)}] \qquad ,i=1,2,...,n</math>
==Method== #Start with initital approximations for <math>x_{1}^{ (1)}, x_{2}^{ (2)},...,x_{n}^{ (n)}</math>. #:Assume <math>x_{i}^{ (1)}=0</math> if no better approximation #Continually iterate through <math>k</math> until stopping condition is met: #:: <math>\vert x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace \forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math> #:<math>or</math> #:: <math>\vert {x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \over x_{i}^{(k)}} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace\forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math>

The Jacobi Iteration Method is used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Base Equation== :<math>x_{i}^{(k+1)} = {1 \over a_{ii}}[b_{i} - \sum\limits_{j=1,j \ne i}^n a_{i,j}x_{j}^{(k)}] \qquad ;i=1,2,...,n</math>
==Method== #Start with initital approximations for <math>x_{1}^{ (1)}, x_{2}^{ (2)},...,x_{n}^{ (n)}</math>. #:Assume <math>x_{i}^{ (1)}=0</math> if no better approximation #Continually iterate through <math>k</math> until stopping condition is met: #:: <math>\vert x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace \forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math> #:<math>or</math> #:: <math>\vert {x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \over x_{i}^{(k)}} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace\forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math>

The Jacobi Iteration Method is used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Base Equation== :<math>x_{i}^{(k+1)} = {1 \over a_{ii}}[b_{i} - \sum\limits_{j=1,j \ne i}^n a_{i,j}x_{j}^{(k)}] \qquad ;i=1,2,...,n</math>
==Method== #Start with initital approximations for <math>x_{1}^{ (1)}, x_{2}^{ (2)},...,x_{n}^{ (n)}</math> #:Assume <math>x_{i}^{ (1)}=0</math> if no better approximation #Continually iterate through <math>k</math> until stopping condition is met: #:: <math>\vert x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace \forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math> #:<math>or</math> #:: <math>\vert {x_{i}^{(k+1)} - x_{i}^{(k)} \over x_{i}^{(k)}} \vert \le \epsilon \qquad ;f\thinspace\forall\thinspace i = 1,2,...,n</math>

A diagram representing a complicated machine, only showing the components which are relevant to the analysis being performed.
*Makes analysis of a machine possible as large intricate machines are much too complicated to analyze at once. ::''i.e. a diesel engine's piston can be broken down to [http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Manivelle_bielle_piston_schematique.svg/250px-Manivelle_bielle_piston_schematique.svg.png this].'' *

revision.text: Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim \atop s \to \infty} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim_{s \to \infty}} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim_{s \to \infty}} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==
If they exists, the following limits are equal:
<math>lim_{t \to \infty} x(t) = lim_{s \to \infty} sX(s)</math>

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim_{s \to \infty}} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==
If they exists, the following limits are equal:
<math>lim_{t \to \infty} x(t) = lim_{s \to \infty} sX(s)</math>
==Transfer Functions==
The transfer function ( H(s) ) of a system is equal to the input ( P(s) ) over the output ( Q(s) ).
<math>H(s) = {P(s) \over Q(s)}</math>
As well, the Transfer function and the Unit Impulse Response of a system are closely related in that they are the Laplace transforms of each other. <math>{H(s) = L(h(t) \brace h(t)) = L^{-1}(H(s))}</math>
==The Delta Function==
The laplace transform of the delta function is 1.
<math>L[ \delta ] = 1</math>
==Solving ODEs Using Laplace Transforms== Laplace transforms can help solve ODEs. It is often easier to solve a complex ODE using this method then other methods.
To solve an ODE, follow these steps:
*1. Take the Laplace Transform of both sides, considering the I.C's at time t = 0-. The following equation is used here: <math>L[y^{(n)}(t)] = s^nY(s) - s^{n-1}y(0) - s^{n-2}y'(0) - ... - y^{n-1}(0)</math> *2. Solve for Y(s). Often partial fractions are used to get the function into a form that it easily transformed back into the time domain. *3. Perform the inverse laplace transform to transform the function back into the time domain.

The following equation is used here: <math>L[y^{(n)}(t)] = s^nY(s) - s^{n-1}y(0) - s^{n-2}y'(0) - ... - y^{(n-1)}(0)</math> *2. Solve for Y(s). Often partial fractions are used to get the function into a form that it easily transformed back into the time domain. *3. Perform the inverse laplace transform to transform the function back into the time domain.
==Stability in the S-Domain==
The stability of a system can be determined from its transfer function.
How is this done?

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Definition== The Laplace transform of a signal is: <math>X(s) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}x(t)e^{-st}dt</math>
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim_{s \to \infty}} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==
If they exists, the following limits are equal:
<math>lim_{t \to \infty} x(t) = lim_{s \to \infty} sX(s)</math>
==Transfer Functions==
The transfer function ( H(s) ) of a system is equal to the input ( P(s) ) over the output ( Q(s) ).
<math>H(s) = {P(s) \over Q(s)}</math>
As well, the Transfer function and the Unit Impulse Response of a system are closely related in that they are the Laplace transforms of each other. <math>{H(s) = L(h(t) \brace h(t)) = L^{-1}(H(s))}</math>
==The Delta Function==
The laplace transform of the delta function is 1.
<math>L[ \delta ] = 1</math>
==Solving ODEs Using Laplace Transforms== Laplace transforms can help solve ODEs. It is often easier to solve a complex ODE using this method then other methods.
To solve an ODE, follow these steps:
*1. Take the Laplace Transform of both sides, considering the I.C's at time t = 0-. The following equation is used here: <math>L[y^{(n)}(t)] = s^nY(s) - s^{n-1}y(0) - s^{n-2}y'(0) - ... - y^{(n-1)}(0)</math> *2. Solve for Y(s). Often partial fractions are used to get the function into a form that it easily transformed back into the time domain. *3. Perform the inverse laplace transform to transform the function back into the time domain.
==Stability in the S-Domain==
The stability of a system can be determined from its transfer function.
How is this done?

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).
==Definition== The Laplace transform of a signal is: <math>X(s) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}x(t)e^{-st}dt</math>
==Initial Value Theorem== If <math>x(t) \longleftrightarrow X(s)</math> exists, then <math>x(0^+) \longleftrightarrow {lim_{s \to \infty}} sX(s)</math> exists.
==Final Value Problem==
If they exists, the following limits are equal:
<math>lim_{t \to \infty} x(t) = lim_{s \to \infty} sX(s)</math>
==Transfer Functions==
The transfer function ( H(s) ) of a system is equal to the input ( P(s) ) over the output ( Q(s) ).
<math>H(s) = {P(s) \over Q(s)}</math>
As well, the Transfer function and the Unit Impulse Response of a system are closely related in that they are the Laplace transforms of each other. <math>{H(s) = L(h(t) \brace h(t)) = L^{-1}(H(s))}</math>
==The Delta Function==
The laplace transform of the delta function is 1.
<math>L[ \delta ] = 1</math>
==Solving ODEs Using Laplace Transforms== Laplace transforms can help solve ODEs. It is often easier to solve a complex ODE using this method then other methods.
To solve an ODE, follow these steps:
*1. Take the Laplace Transform of both sides, considering the I.C's at time t = 0-. The following equation is used here: <math>L[y^{(n)}(t)] = s^nY(s) - s^{n-1}y(0) - s^{n-2}y'(0) - ... - y^{(n-1)}(0)</math> *2. Solve for Y(s). Often partial fractions are used to get the function into a form that it easily transformed back into the time domain. *3. Perform the inverse laplace transform to transform the function back into the time domain.
==Stability in the S-Domain==
The stability of a system can be determined from its transfer function.
rules: *1. The system is asymptotically stable iff all the poles of the transfer function are in the left hand plane *2. The system is unstable if at least one pole of the transfer function is in the RHP, or here are repeated poles on the imaginary axis. *3. The system is marginally stable iff there are no poles of the transfer function in the RHP and some poles are on the imaginary axis.

Laplace transforms allow us to convert a function from the Time Domain to the Frequency domain (and vice-versa).

<math>L[ \delta ] = 1</math>

*1. Take the Laplace Transform of both sides, considering the I.C's at time t = 0-. The following equation is used here: <math>L[y^{(n)}(t)] = s^nY(s) - s^{n-1}y(0) - s^{n-2}y'(0) - ... - y^{(n-1)}(0)</math> *2. Solve for Y(s). Often partial fractions are used to get the function into a form that it easily transformed back into the time domain. *3. Perform the inverse laplace transform to transform the function back into the time domain.

The stability of a system can be determined from its transfer function.
rules: *1. The system is asymptotically stable iff all the poles of the transfer function are in the left hand plane *2. The system is unstable if at least one pole of the transfer function is in the RHP, or here are repeated poles on the imaginary axis. *3. The system is marginally stable iff there are no poles of the transfer function in the RHP and some poles are on the imaginary axis.

revision.comment: Created page with "Least squares regression is one of many curve fitting methods available to engineers. This method is a simple method of finding the best straight line to fit a given set of data...."
Created page with "== Goal == Used to solve a system of linear equations. ==Overview== Any square matrix [A] can be written as a combination of two matrices such that: <math>[A]=[L][U]</math> == ..."
revision.text:
== Goal == Used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Overview== Any square matrix [A] can be written as a combination of two matrices such that: <math>[A]=[L][U]</math>
== Upper Matrix == The following is an example of an upper matrix: <math>[U] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right)</math>
== Lower Matrix == The following is an example of a lower matrix: <math>[L] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{array} \right)</math>
== Method ==

== Goal == Used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Overview== Any square matrix [A] can be written as a combination of two matrices such that: <math>[A]=[L][U]</math>
== Upper Matrix == The following is an example of an upper matrix: <math>[U] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} u_{1,1} & u_{1,2} & u_{1,3} \\ 0 & u_{2,2} & u_{2,3} \\ 0 & 0 & u_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>
== Lower Matrix == The following is an example of a lower matrix: <math>[L] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} l_{1,1} & 0 & 0 \\ l_{2,1} & l_{2,2} & 0 \\ l_{3,1} & l_{3,2} & l_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>
== Method ==

== Goal == Used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Overview== Any square matrix [A] can be written as a combination of two matrices such that: <math>[A]=[L][U]</math>. This concept is used, for example, in Crout's and Choleski's method.
== Upper Matrix == The following is an example of an upper matrix: <math>[U] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} u_{1,1} & u_{1,2} & u_{1,3} \\ 0 & u_{2,2} & u_{2,3} \\ 0 & 0 & u_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>
== Lower Matrix == The following is an example of a lower matrix: <math>[L] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} l_{1,1} & 0 & 0 \\ l_{2,1} & l_{2,2} & 0 \\ l_{3,1} & l_{3,2} & l_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>

== Goal == Used to solve a system of linear equations.
==Overview== Any square matrix [A] can be written as a combination of two matrices such that: <math>[A]=[L][U]</math>. This concept is used, for example, in [[Crout's Method]] and [[Choleski's Method]].
== Upper Matrix == The following is an example of an upper matrix: <math>[U] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} u_{1,1} & u_{1,2} & u_{1,3} \\ 0 & u_{2,2} & u_{2,3} \\ 0 & 0 & u_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>
== Lower Matrix == The following is an example of a lower matrix: <math>[L] = \left( \begin{array}{ccc} l_{1,1} & 0 & 0 \\ l_{2,1} & l_{2,2} & 0 \\ l_{3,1} & l_{3,2} & l_{3,3} \end{array} \right)</math>

==Kinematics and Dynamics of Machines== Principles of the geometry of motion, Uniform and non-uniform motion, linkage, gears, cams. Synthesis and analysis of mechanisms. Consideration of the static and dynamic forces in machines. Vibration analysis, response to shock, motion and force transmissibility, vibration isolation.

MTE 204 - Numerical Methods

MTE 204 - Numerical Methods
==Sensors and Instrumentation== Review of circuit theory; input-output relationships, transfer functions and frequency response of linear systems; operational amplifiers, operational amplifier circuits using negative or positive feedback; diodes, operational amplifier circuits using diodes; analog signal detection, conditioning and conversion systems; transducers and sensors, difference and instrumentation amplifiers, active filters.

MTE 204 - Numerical Methods
==Numerical Methods== Number systems and machine errors; Roots of non-linear equations; Matrix calculations; Eigenvalues and eigenvector calculations; Interpolation and approximation; Numerical integration and solution of ODEs (linear and non-linear) and systems of ODEs; Calculation of series; Solution methods for PDEs; Use of numeric and symbolic computing tools.

MTE 204 - Numerical Methods
==Numerical Methods== Number systems and machine errors; Roots of non-linear equations; Matrix calculations; Eigenvalues and eigenvector calculations; Interpolation and approximation; Numerical integration and solution of ODEs (linear and non-linear) and systems of ODEs; Calculation of series; Solution methods for PDEs; Use of numeric and symbolic computing tools.
__TOC__
==Study Help / MTE 204 by topic==
Lecture Topics: *Instability in Numerical Solutions *[[Computational Error]] *Significant Digits *Number Base Conversion (i.e. Decimal -> Binary) *Rounding & Computation Errors *Non-Linear Equations '''Finding Roots''' *[[Finding Roots Numerically]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Incremental_Search_Method|Incremental Search]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Bisection_Method|Bisection Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Newton-Raphson_Method|Newton-Raphson Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Secant_Method|Secant Method]] '''Solving Equations''' *Simultaneous Linear Equations (know Euclidean/Vector norms and other content from handout that was covered in class) *[[Gaussian Elimination Method]] *[[Gauss-Jordan Elimination Method]] *[[Lower/Upper Decomposition Method]] (formulas for entries will be provided) *[[Jacobi Iteration Method]] *[[Gauss-Seidel Iteration Methods]] *[[Choleski Method]] '''Curve Fitting''' *Collocation Polynomial Fit *Interpolation Using Newton’s Divided Difference Method

==Numerical Methods== Number systems and machine errors; Roots of non-linear equations; Matrix calculations; Eigenvalues and eigenvector calculations; Interpolation and approximation; Numerical integration and solution of ODEs (linear and non-linear) and systems of ODEs; Calculation of series; Solution methods for PDEs; Use of numeric and symbolic computing tools.
__TOC__
==Study Help / MTE 204 by topic==
Lecture Topics: *Instability in Numerical Solutions *[[Computational Error]] *Significant Digits *Number Base Conversion (i.e. Decimal -> Binary) *Rounding & Computation Errors *Non-Linear Equations '''Finding Roots''' *[[Finding Roots Numerically]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Incremental_Search_Method|Incremental Search]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Bisection_Method|Bisection Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Newton-Raphson_Method|Newton-Raphson Method]] *[[Finding Roots Numerically#Secant_Method|Secant Method]] '''Solving Equations''' *Simultaneous Linear Equations (know Euclidean/Vector norms and other content from handout that was covered in class) *[[Gaussian Elimination Method]] *[[Gauss-Jordan Elimination Method]] *[[Lower/Upper Decomposition Method]] (formulas for entries will be provided) *[[Jacobi Iteration Method]] *[[Gauss-Seidel Iteration Methods]] *[[Choleski Method]] '''Curve Fitting''' *Collocation Polynomial Fit *Interpolation Using Newton’s Divided Difference Method '''Regression''' *Linear Regression [[Regression]] *Polynomial Regression [[Regression]] *Missing lecture #20 material... '''Numerical Differentiation''' *Finite difference approximations [[Numerical Differentiation]] *Taylor Series Expansions [[Numerical Differentiation]]
==Links== [[2B Midterms#MTE_220|Midterm Information]]
[http://tutorial.math.lamar.edu/Classes/LinAlg/LinAlg.aspx/ Paul's Notes: Linear Algebra]

==Files==
==Important Dates==

MTE 220

==Sensors and Instrumentation== Review of circuit theory; input-output relationships, transfer functions and frequency response of linear systems; operational amplifiers, operational amplifier circuits using negative or positive feedback; diodes, operational amplifier circuits using diodes; analog signal detection, conditioning and conversion systems; transducers and sensors, difference and instrumentation amplifiers, active filters.

==Textbooks== '''JOHNSON''':PROCESS CONTROL INSTRUMENTATION TECHNOLOGY 8ED (ISBN: 9780131194571)

==Sensors and Instrumentation== Review of circuit theory; input-output relationships, transfer functions and frequency response of linear systems; operational amplifiers, operational amplifier circuits using negative or positive feedback; diodes, operational amplifier circuits using diodes; analog signal detection, conditioning and conversion systems; transducers and sensors, difference and instrumentation amplifiers, active filters.
For information regarding the midterm, have at look at the 2B Midterms page: [[2B Midterms#MTE_220]]

==Introduction to Computer Structures & Real-Time Systems== Introduction to computer organization, basic real-time concepts, process management, interprocess communication and synchronization, memory management, resource management, interrupt handling, concurrent programming, file systems.
==MTE 241 by topic== *Populate me with links topic specific information.
==Compiled Exam Information==
Questions Expected to Appear: The prof said that there will be four questions on the exam, closely following the format of previous year's exams. They will cover the following topics: 1. RTOS, project based question. This will probably involve making a modification to the existing project base. 2. Unix fork operation. 3. Disk I/O, I/O transfer. 4. A mash-up of smaller questions, for example, something about processes/threads.
Two midterms with solutions are available on the EngSoc website.

revision.comment: Created page with "==Actuators and Power Electronics== Review of circuit analysis and basic electromagnetic theory. Power electronics: power electronic circuits, H bridges, PWM control, interfacing..."
revision.text:
==Actuators and Power Electronics== Review of circuit analysis and basic electromagnetic theory. Power electronics: power electronic circuits, H bridges, PWM control, interfacing, power amplifiers. DC servo & stepper motors, AC synchronous & induction motors. Transformers. Introduction to typical speed and torque control techniques of motors.

==Actuators and Power Electronics== Review of circuit analysis and basic electromagnetic theory. Power electronics: power electronic circuits, H bridges, PWM control, interfacing, power amplifiers. DC servo & stepper motors, AC synchronous & induction motors. Transformers. Introduction to typical speed and torque control techniques of motors.
