revision.comment: Created page with "== MathCAD Lab Help =="
revision.text: == MathCAD Lab Help ==

== MathCAD == So far my associates and my experience with MathCAD has been one of playing with finicky syntax over any beneficial harnessing of computer power. It seems to be a lesser known cousin of the better known MATLAB, where reasons of why we use the sooner are beyond me. Complaints aside, the following are simple fixes to common syntax problems: *MathCAD executes from top-to-bottom. Using a variable to the right of where you declared it may result in an error as it is located slightly above the declaration *MathCAD re-executes all items following (below) a change made to your code *Using a "." as a shortcut to subscript of (ex. <math> A.1 = >A_{1}</math> ) is sometimes not considered the same as clicking the subtext button, like when specifying points from a matrix <math> f(x_{1},y_{1}) </math>. *Pressing Ctrl + '=' instead of just '='; they are indistinguishable in the Lab tutorial notes, but mean a world of difference. Ctrl + '=' is used after a 'Given' statement, when setting an existing function to a value, ex. <math>f(x)=0</math> to solve the roots. The ':=' is used to set a variable to a certain value, and plain old '=' returns the value stored in a variable.
== Lab 2 Help ==

== MathCAD == So far my associates and my experience with MathCAD has been one of playing with finicky syntax over any beneficial harnessing of computer power. It seems to be a lesser known cousin of the better known MATLAB, where reasons of why we use the sooner are beyond me. Complaints aside, the following are simple fixes to common syntax problems: *MathCAD executes from top-to-bottom. Using a variable to the right of where you declared it may result in an error as it is located slightly above the declaration *MathCAD re-executes all items following (below) a change made to your code *Using a "." as a shortcut to subscript of (ex. <math> A.1 = >A_{1}</math> ) is sometimes not considered the same as clicking the subtext button, like when specifying points from a matrix <math> f(x_{1},y_{1}) </math>. *Pressing 'Ctrl + =' instead of just '='; they are indistinguishable in the Lab tutorial notes, but mean a world of difference. Ctrl + '=' is used after a 'Given' statement, when setting an existing function to a value, ex. <math>f(x)=0</math> to solve the roots. The ':=' is used to set a variable to a certain value, and plain old '=' returns the value stored in a variable.
== Lab 2 Help ==

== MathCAD == So far my associates and my experience with MathCAD has been one of playing with finicky syntax over any beneficial harnessing of computer power. It seems to be a lesser known cousin of the better known MATLAB, where reasons of why we use the sooner are beyond me. Complaints aside, the following are simple fixes to common syntax problems: *MathCAD executes from top-to-bottom. Using a variable to the right of where you declared it may result in an error as it is located slightly above the declaration *MathCAD re-executes all items following (below) a change made to your code *Using a "." as a shortcut to subscript of (ex. <math> A.1 = >A_{1}</math> ) is sometimes not considered the same as clicking the subtext button, like when specifying points from a matrix <math> f(x_{1},y_{1}) </math>. *Pressing 'Ctrl + =' instead of just '='; they are indistinguishable in the Lab tutorial notes, but mean a world of difference. Ctrl + '=' is used after a 'Given' statement, when setting an existing function to a value, ex. <math>f(x)=0</math> to solve the roots. The ':=' is used to set a variable to a certain value, and plain old '=' returns the value stored in a variable.
== Lab 2 Help == I recommended doing the tutorial before or in tandem with this lab as it tells you everything you need to know. Horray. However, as a few of us found out, you can get away with some major syntax error in the tutorial and still get the right answers because there is only one critical point, but the lab will not work. A few hints for this one include: * For the i..n command; there is a '..' symbol in the ''Matrix'' toolbar * TODO

== MathCAD == So far my associates and my experience with MathCAD has been one of playing with finicky syntax over any beneficial harnessing of computer power. It seems to be a lesser known cousin of the better known MATLAB, where reasons of why we use the sooner are beyond me. Complaints aside, the following are simple fixes to common syntax problems: *MathCAD executes from top-to-bottom. Using a variable to the right of where you declared it may result in an error as it is located slightly above the declaration *MathCAD re-executes all items following (below) a change made to your code *Using a "." as a shortcut to subscript of (ex. <math> A.1 = >A_{1}</math> ) is sometimes not considered the same as clicking the subtext button, like when specifying points from a matrix <math> f(x_{1},y_{1}) </math>. *Pressing 'Ctrl + =' instead of just '='; they are indistinguishable in the Lab tutorial notes, but mean a world of difference. Ctrl + '=' is used after a 'Given' statement, when setting an existing function to a value, ex. <math>f(x)=0</math> to solve the roots. The ':=' is used to set a variable to a certain value, and plain old '=' returns the value stored in a variable.
== Lab 2 Help == I recommended doing the tutorial before or in tandem with this lab as it tells you everything you need to know. Horray. However, as a few of us found out, you can get away with some major syntax error in the tutorial and still get the right answers because there is only one critical point, but the lab will not work. A few hints for this one include: * For the i..n command; there is a '..' symbol in the ''Matrix'' toolbar * The above syntax problems are always an issue * Because there are two critical points, remember to calculate the Hessian for <math>f(x_{1},y_{1})</math> as well as <math>f(x_{2},y_{2})</math>.

revision.comment: Created page with "==Mechanical Joints== ====Links==== :The building blocks of all mechanisms. :'''Types''' ::*Binary (Two Nodes) ::*Ternary (Three Nodes) ::*Quaternary (Four) ::*etc ====Classify..."
revision.text:
==Mechanical Joints==
====Links==== :The building blocks of all mechanisms. :'''Types''' ::*Binary (Two Nodes) ::*Ternary (Three Nodes) ::*Quaternary (Four) ::*etc
====Classifying Joints==== :A connection between links which allows relative motion. (''i.e. Pin, Slider, etc.'') Can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) ::*Two DOF (Half Joint)
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

==Mechanical Joints==
====Links==== :The building blocks of all mechanisms. :'''Types''' ::*Binary (Two Nodes) ::*Ternary (Three Nodes) ::*Quaternary (Four) ::*etc
====Classifying Joints==== :A connection between links which allows relative motion. (''i.e. Pin, Slider, etc.'') Can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

====Classifying Joints==== :A connection between links which allows relative motion. (''i.e. Pin, Slider, etc.'') Can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

====Classifying Joints==== :A connection between links which allows relative motion. (''i.e. Pin, Slider, etc.'') Can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together, [http://www.stainlessmarinefixings.com/Marine%20Images/Spring%20Hook%2001.png example]'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

====Classifying Joints==== :A connection between links which allows relative motion. (''i.e. Pin, Slider, etc.'') Can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together, the caribiner shown [http://www.stainlessmarinefixings.com/Marine%20Images/Spring%20Hook%2001.png here] is held closed by a spring in the pin joint'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

====Classifying Joints==== :A joint is a connection between links which allows relative motion. Joints can be classified by:
:'''1. Type of Contact''' ::*Lower pairs (Surface contact) ::*Higher pairs (Point or line contact)
:'''2. Degrees of Freedom''' ::*One DOF (Full Joint) :::''i.e. Pin, [http://lh6.ggpht.com/_EIVSr-XQ0JU/SZK0yugFJAI/AAAAAAAAD5g/aBPR1jHZ02g/rocklerslide.jpg Slider]'' ::*Two DOF (Half Joint) :::''i.e. Cam
:'''3. Order of Joint''' ::Number of links -1 :::''i.e. 2nd order joint has three links''
:'''4. Physical Closure''' ::*Form-closed Joints :::''i.e. an external spring acting on one link holding the joint together, the caribiner shown [http://www.stainlessmarinefixings.com/Marine%20Images/Spring%20Hook%2001.png here] is held closed by a spring in the pin joint'' ::*Force-closed Joints :::''i.e. the geometry of the joint keeps the joint together - no external force''

revision.comment: Created page with "== Extrema of Functions =="
revision.text: == Extrema of Functions ==

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a relative maximum of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2U}{\partial x^2} = 0 \frac{\partial^2U}{\partial y^2} = 0 </math>

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a relative maximum of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 </math>

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a relative maximum of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie: } <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nalba f} = 0</math>

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
===Second Derivative Test===

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
===Second Derivative Test=== Once the location of the critical points has been determined with the 1st derivative test, the second derivative test helps classify what type of critical point it is.
====Procedure==== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=A*C-B^2</math>
Then, if: *D > 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D > 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D < 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
===Second Derivative Test=== Once the location of the critical points has been determined with the 1st derivative test, the second derivative test helps classify what type of critical point it is.
====Procedure==== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=A*C-B^2</math>
Then, if: *D > 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D > 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D < 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
==Absolute Maxima / Minima==
====Find Relative Maxima / Minima==== To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
====Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)==== [[Twiki Todo]]
====Find Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum====
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps.

== Extrema of Functions ==
Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
===The first derivative test=== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
===Second Derivative Test=== Once the location of the critical points has been determined with the 1st derivative test, the second derivative test helps classify what type of critical point it is.
====Procedure==== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=A*C-B^2</math>
Then, if: *D > 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D > 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D < 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
==Absolute Maxima / Minima==
===Procedure=== *'''Find Relative Maxima / Minima''' To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
*'''Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)''' [[Twiki Todo]]
*'''Find Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum'''
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps.

== Extrema of Functions ==
===Relative Maxima/Minima=== Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
====The first derivative test==== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>

=====Procedure===== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=A*C-B^2</math>
Then, if: *D > 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D > 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D < 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
==Absolute Maxima / Minima==
===Procedure=== *'''Find Relative Maxima / Minima''' To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
*'''Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)''' [[Twiki Todo]]
*'''Find Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum'''
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps.

== Extrema of Functions ==
===Relative Maxima/Minima=== Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
====The first derivative test==== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2} = 0 , \frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
====Second Derivative Test==== Once the location of the critical points has been determined with the 1st derivative test, the second derivative test helps classify what type of critical point it is.
=====Procedure===== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=A*C-B^2</math>
Then, if: *D > 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D > 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D < 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist

===Absolute Maxima / Minima===

*'''Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)''' Find the equation of the boundary and then evaluate it to determine what the maxima/minima of the boudary equations are.
*'''Evaluate Absolute Maximum / Minimum'''
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps. Then compare them to the relative maxima and minima found in the function and determine which are absolute extrema.

==Lagrange Multipliers==
Lagrange Multipliers allow allow us to find the maximums and minimums on the boundary of an equation, by subjecting it to a cosntraint.
The constraint is called g. The function is f. At the extremum located on the boundary of f, the gradients of f and g are equal. Therefore we try to solve the following equation.
<math>\nablaf = \lambda \nabla g</math>
Our goal is to find the values of lambda that satisfy this equation. Then we find the associated X, Y points and those are the critical points on the boundary of f. Then characterize these critical points.

== Extrema of Functions ==
===Relative Maxima/Minima=== Finding the extrema (maximums, minimums and saddle points [which are the equivalent of points of inflection in 2d calc]) draws many similarities to two-dimensional calculus, but it admittedly a bit harder.
====The first derivative test==== At a '''relative maximum''' of a function f where x=a and y=b, the then first partial derivatives equal zero, as does the gradient of the function. ie:
<math>\frac{\partial f}{\partial x} = 0 , \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = 0 , \vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = 0</math>
A point (a,b) is a '''critical point''' if one of the following is true:
*<math>\vec {\nabla f}_{a,b} = \vec 0</math> *<math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial x^2}</math> and/ or <math>\frac{\partial^2f}{\partial y^2}</math> does not exist.
A point (a,b) is a '''saddle point''' when <math>f(x,y)>f(a,b) & f(x,y)<f(a,b)</math>
====Second Derivative Test==== Once the location of the critical points has been determined with the 1st derivative test, the second derivative test helps classify what type of critical point it is.
=====Procedure===== Define three variables: <math>A=f_{xx}(a,b), B = f_{xy}(a,b), C = f_{yy}(a,b)</math>, and determine the Hessian of F which is called D. <math>D(a,b)=B^2 - A*C</math>
Then, if: *D < 0 and A < 0, (a,b) is a relative maximum *D < 0 and A > 0, (a,b) is a relative minimum *D > 0, (a,b) is a saddle point *D = 0, (a,b) may be a relative maximum or minimum or a saddle point (this case is not covered in MTE 203)
Finding critical points is a key concept in calculus as it allows you to find optimized values in many situations.
A critical point of a graph is defined as a point which satitsfies one of the following conditions: # <math>\nabla f(a,b) = 0</math> # <math>f_{x}(a,b)</math> does not exist # <math>f_{y}(a,b)</math> does not exist
===Absolute Maxima / Minima===
====Procedure==== *'''Find Relative Maxima / Minima''' To find the relative maxima and minima, see the section above.
*'''Find Boundary Maxima / Minima (Extrema)''' Find the equation of the boundary. This is done by parameterizing the boundary and then substituting the results obtained into the original surface's function. Then evaluate it to determine what the maxima/minima of the boundary equations are.
*'''Evaluate and Characterize Absolute Maximum / Minimum'''
This step is the easiest of the three steps. To find the absolute maximum or minimum, evaluate the value of the function at each of the critical points identified in the previous steps. Then compare them to the relative maxima and minima found in the function and determine which are absolute extrema.
==Lagrange Multipliers==
Lagrange Multipliers allow allow us to find the maximums and minimums on the boundary of an equation, by subjecting it to a cosntraint.
The constraint is called g. The function is f. At the extremum located on the boundary of f, the gradients of f and g are equal. Therefore we try to solve the following equation.
<math>\nabla f = \lambda \nabla g</math>
Our goal is to find the values of lambda that satisfy this equation. Then we find the associated X, Y points and those are the critical points on the boundary of f. Then characterize these critical points.

revision.text:
==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>df(x)\overdx \mid_{x_0}</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation===

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives.Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^(n)(x_i) + ...</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.

==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point forward-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.

==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>

==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math>

The topic of Numerical Differentiation is discussed in MTE 204 lecture #21.
==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>

The topic of Numerical Differentiation is discussed in MTE 204 lecture #21.
==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==

revision.comment: /* Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators */
revision.text:
The topic of Numerical Differentiation is discussed in MTE 204 lecture #21.
==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==
This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>

This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>

<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math> operator <math>\Delta</math> ===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==
This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>

The topic of Numerical Differentiation is discussed in MTE 204 lecture #21.

<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>

===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>

This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations of Partial Derivatives==
</math>\del^2 f(x,y) \over \del x^2</math>

<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===

===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>

<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>

===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==
This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations of Partial Derivatives==
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2} \approx {f(x_i+1,y_j) - f(x_i,y_i) \over \Delta x</math>

revision.text:
The topic of Numerical Differentiation is discussed in MTE 204 lecture #21.
==Definition of a Derivative== Just in case it comes in handy, the basic definition of a derivative is:
<math>{df(x)\over dx}\mid_{x_0} = lim_{x\to x_0} {f(x) - f(x_0) \over x - x_0}</math>
==Basic Finite Difference Approximations== There are three ways discussed in MTE 204 to numerically approximate derivatives. These are the most commonly used methods of approximating derivatives.Their formulae follow. ===Two Point Forward-Difference Approximations===
<math> x = x_i + \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i+1} - x_i} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math> operator <math>\Delta</math> ===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==
This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations of Partial Derivatives==
'''Forward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Backward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i-1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j-1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Central Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_{i-1},y_j) \over 2\Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_{j-1}) \over 2\Delta y</math>

===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>

This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations of Partial Derivatives== ===First Partials=== '''Forward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Backward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i-1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j-1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Central Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_{i-1},y_j) \over 2\Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_{j-1}) \over 2\Delta y</math>
===Second Partials=== Second partials were also covered in MTE204, the equations are given in the book (end of lecture #22).

===Two point backard-difference approximation=== <math> x = x_i - \Delta x, \Delta x > 0:</math> <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i-1}) - f(x_{i}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} = {f(x_{i}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i-1} - x_i} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
===Two point central-difference approximation=== <math>{f'(x) \approx {f(x_{i+1}) - f(x_{i-1}) \over x_{i+1} - x_{i-1}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over 2\Delta x}</math>
==Using Taylor Series Expansions== Taylor series expansions can be used to numerically determine derivatives. Barring the derivation of this method (as usual...) the useful equations follow.
For <math>x = x_i - \Delta x</math> the derivative of f is:
<math> f(x_i + \Delta x) = f(x_i) + \Delta x f'(x_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2!}f''(x_i) - {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f'''(x_i) + ... + {(-\Delta x)^n \over n!}f^{(n)}(x_i) + ...</math>
Using the Taylor Series approximation method leads to some error. IE, the calculated value of the derivative is not the exact value but merely an approximation of that value. The error of the ''n''th term is calculated by:
<math>R_n = {(x - x_i)^{n + 1} \over (n + 1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi) = {(\Delta x)^{(n+1)} \over (n+1)!}f^{(n+1)}(\xi)</math>
Where <math>\xi</math> is a value between x_i and x.
This error is reduced as <math>\Delta x</math> is reduced.
==Finite-Difference Approximation of Second Derivatives== Expanding on the finite-difference approximations of first derivatives, we can find equations of the forward-difference, backward-difference and central difference of second derivatives.
===Forward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+2} - 2f_{i+1} + f_i \over \Delta x^2 }</math> operator <math>\Delta</math> ===Backward Difference Approximation=== <math>f''_i \approx { f_{i}-2f_{i-1} + f_{i-2} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
===Central Difference Approximation===
<math>f''_i \approx { f_{i+1} - 2f_{i} + f_{i-1} \over \Delta x^2 }</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations for Higher Order Derivatives== Forward, central and backward approximations can be determined for any order derivative. The equations are given in MTE 204 lecture 22, and in the course textbook.
==Approximations of Derivatives using Difference Operators==
This offers a different approach for approximating derivatives of any order.
===Important Operators=== '''Forward Difference''' operator <math>\Delta</math>
<math>\Delta f_i = f_{i+1} - f_i</math>
'''Backward Difference''' operator <math>\nabla</math>
<math>\nabla f_i = f_{i} - f_{i-1}</math>
'''Central Difference''' operator <math>\delta</math>
<math>\delta f_i = f_{i+{1 \over 2}} - f_{i- {1 \over 2}}</math>
====Powers of Operators==== An operator can be squared etc as such: <math>\Delta^2 = \Delta(\Delta)</math>
====Examples==== The derivatives can be obtained using the operators as in the following examples: '''Forward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\Delta f \over \Delta x} = {f_{i+1} - f_i \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Backward Difference''' <math>{{df \over dx} \approx {\nabla f \over \Delta x} ={f_{i} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
'''Central Difference''' <math>{{{df \over dx} \approx {\delta f \over \Delta x}} = {f_{i+1} - f_{i-1} \over \Delta x}</math>
==Finite Difference Approximations of Partial Derivatives== ===First Partials=== '''Forward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Backward Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i-1},y_j) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j-1}) - f(x_i,y_j) \over \Delta y</math>
'''Central Difference'''
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial x^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_{i+1},y_j) - f(x_{i-1},y_j) \over 2\Delta x</math>
<math>{\partial^2 f(x,y) \over \partial y^2}\vert x_i,y_j \approx {f(x_i,y_{j+1}) - f(x_i,y_{j-1}) \over 2\Delta y</math>
===Second Partials=== Second partials were also covered in MTE204, the equations are given in the book (end of lecture #22).
==Newton-Cotes Formulas==

==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math>

==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>

==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h \longrightarrow I_i = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule===

==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule===

==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule=== Simpson's rule uses higher order polynomials to approximate the area under a curve.
====The One-Third Rule====
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>

I is the integral of the function.

Numerical integration was discussed in MTE 204 lectures 23 and 24.
==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule=== Simpson's rule uses higher order polynomials to approximate the area under a curve.
====The One-Third Rule====
Second order polynomials are used to approximate the area under the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>
==Richardson's Extrapolation==
These formulas help achieve a more accurate integral by interpolating between two approximated integrals.
===R.E. as it Applies to the Trapezoidal Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^2 -1}</math>
===R.E. as it Applies to Simpson's One-Third Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^4 -1}</math>
==Gauss Quadrature Method== The main advantage of using this method is that you do not need to evaluate the integral at multiple points as they are calculated as part of the method.
===Method=== *1.Coordinate transformation: <math>dx \to {a-b\over 2}d\bar x</math>

===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.

====The One-Third Rule====
Second order polynomials are used to approximate the area under the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>
==Richardson's Extrapolation==
These formulas help achieve a more accurate integral by interpolating between two approximated integrals.
===R.E. as it Applies to the Trapezoidal Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^2 -1}</math>
===R.E. as it Applies to Simpson's One-Third Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^4 -1}</math>
