===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule=== Simpson's rule uses higher order polynomials to approximate the area under a curve.
====The One-Third Rule====
Second order polynomials are used to approximate the area under the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>
==Richardson's Extrapolation==
These formulas help achieve a more accurate integral by interpolating between two approximated integrals.
===R.E. as it Applies to the Trapezoidal Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^2 -1}</math>
===R.E. as it Applies to Simpson's One-Third Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^4 -1}</math>
==Gauss Quadrature Method== The main advantage of using this method is that you do not need to evaluate the integral at multiple points as they are calculated as part of the method.
===Method=== *1.Coordinate transformation: <math>dx \to {a-b\over 2}d\bar x</math>:
<math>I \approx{b-a\over 2}\sum_{i=1}^n(w_i \bar f(x_i))</math>
Where n is a predefined number of Gauss points. xi and wi are Gauss points and weights.
With <math>x = \varphi(\bar x) = a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a)
*2.Calculate the Gauss points and weights. This process will be described in the following sections.
*3.
See 2-poitn quadrature for a condensed application of this method.
===Calculation of Gauss Points and Weights===
====2-Point Gauss Quadrature==== Two Gauss points are taken.
<math>f(\varpi( \bar x)) = f(a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a))</math>
It is hard to apply the method with more than 2 Gauss points. More than 2 points were not covered in MTE 204.
==Gauss-Legendre Method==

Numerical integration was discussed in MTE 204 lectures 23 and 24.
==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule=== Simpson's rule uses higher order polynomials to approximate the area under a curve.
====The One-Third Rule====
Second order polynomials are used to approximate the area under the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>
==Richardson's Extrapolation==
These formulas help achieve a more accurate integral by interpolating between two approximated integrals.
===R.E. as it Applies to the Trapezoidal Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^2 -1}</math>
===R.E. as it Applies to Simpson's One-Third Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^4 -1}</math>
==Gauss Quadrature Method== The main advantage of using this method is that you do not need to evaluate the integral at multiple points as they are calculated as part of the method.
===Method=== *1.Coordinate transformation: <math>dx \to {a-b\over 2}d\bar x</math>:
<math>I \approx{b-a\over 2}\sum_{i=1}^n(w_i \bar f(x_i))</math>
Where n is a predefined number of Gauss points. xi and wi are Gauss points and weights.
With <math>x = \varphi(\bar x) = a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a)</math>
*2.Calculate the Gauss points and weights. This process will be described in the following sections.
*3.
See 2-poitn quadrature for a condensed application of this method.
===Calculation of Gauss Points and Weights===
====2-Point Gauss Quadrature==== Two Gauss points are taken.
<math>f(\varpi( \bar x)) = f(a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a))</math>
It is hard to apply the method with more than 2 Gauss points. More than 2 points were not covered in MTE 204.
==Gauss-Legendre Method==

Numerical integration was discussed in MTE 204 lectures 23 and 24.
==Newton-Cotes Formulas== This method involves replacing the function to be integrated by an approximating function (Pm(x)) which is easier to integrate. The following rules help to determine Pm(x).
===Rectangular Rule=== A series of rectangles are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method==== Find points <math>x_i = a + ih , i=1,2,3...n</math>
<math>f(x_i) = f_i</math>
Then: *1.<math>I_i \approx f_ih \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} f_i)</math> *2.<math>I_i \approx f_{i+1}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^n f_i)</math> *3.<math>I_i \approx {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2}h \to \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=1}^{n-1} {f_i+f_{i+1} \over 2})</math>
===Trapezoidal Rule=== A series of trapezoids are used to approximate the area under a curve.
====Method====
<math>I_i \approx {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}h</math> with <math> I = \int_a^b f(x)dx \approx h(\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} {f_i + f_{i+1} \over 2}) = h{f_0 + f_n \over 2} + h \sum_{i=1}^{n-1}f_i</math>
I is the integral of the function.
===Simpson's Rule=== Simpson's rule uses higher order polynomials to approximate the area under a curve.
====The One-Third Rule====
Second order polynomials are used to approximate the area under the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx = \sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} I_i \approx {h \over 3}(\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_{i-1} + 4f_i + f{i+1}))={h \over 3}(f_0 + 4\sum_{1=1,3,5...}^{n-1} (f_i + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=2,4,6...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_n))</math>
====One-Eighth Rule====
Similar to One-Third rule except that third order polynomials are used to approximate the curve.
<math>I = \int_a^bf(x)dx \approx {3h\over 8}(f_0 + 3\sum_{1=1,4,7...}^{n-2} (f_i + f_{i+2} + 2)) + 2\sum_{1=3,6,9...}^{n-3} (f_i + f_n))</math>
==Richardson's Extrapolation==
These formulas help achieve a more accurate integral by interpolating between two approximated integrals.
===R.E. as it Applies to the Trapezoidal Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^2 -1}</math>
===R.E. as it Applies to Simpson's One-Third Rule=== <math>I \approx I_1h_1 + {I_11h_1 - I_2h_2 \over ({h_2 \over h_1})^4 -1}</math>
==Gauss Quadrature Method== The main advantage of using this method is that you do not need to evaluate the integral at multiple points as they are calculated as part of the method.
===Method=== *1.Coordinate transformation: <math>dx \to {a-b\over 2}d\bar x</math>:
<math>I \approx{b-a\over 2}\sum_{i=1}^n(w_i \bar f(x_i))</math>
Where n is a predefined number of Gauss points. xi and wi are Gauss points and weights.
With <math>x = \varphi(\bar x) = a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a)</math>
*2.Calculate the Gauss points and weights. This process will be described in the following sections.
*3.
See 2-poitn quadrature for a condensed application of this method.
===Calculation of Gauss Points and Weights===
====2-Point Gauss Quadrature==== Two Gauss points are taken.
<math>f(\varpi( \bar x)) = f(a + {\bar x + 1 \over 2}(b - a))</math>
It is hard to apply the method with more than 2 Gauss points. More than 2 points were not covered in MTE 204.
==Gauss-Legendre Method== ===n-Point Gauss-Legendre Quadrature Formula===
<math> I \approx {b-a\over 2}\sum_{i=1}^n(w_i\bar f(x_i))</math>
The weights are given by:
<math>w_i = {{2(1-x_i^2)} \over {(nP_{n-1}(x_i))^2}}</math>

revision.comment: Created page with " ==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems. <math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>"
revision.text:
==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems.
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>

==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems.
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>
==Heun's Method==
For step i=1,2,3... and with an IC given as <math>x(x_0,y_0)</math>
# <math>y_{i+1}^(0) = y_i + \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math> Note, this step uses Euler's method. # <math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i + \Delta x{f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^(0)) \over 2}</math>

==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems.
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>
==Heun's Method==
For step i=1,2,3... and with an IC given as <math>x(x_0,y_0)</math>
# <math>y_{i+1}^{(0)} = y_i + \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math> Note, this step uses Euler's method. # <math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i + \Delta x{f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^{(0)}) \over 2}</math>

==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems.
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>
==Heun's Method==
For step i=1,2,3... and with an IC given as <math>x(x_0,y_0)</math>
# <math>y_{i+1}^{(0)} = y_i + \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math> Note, this step uses Euler's method. # <math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i + \Delta x{f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^{(0)}) \over 2}</math>
Heun's Method can be improved by adding one more step, and by adding a stopping criterion.
# Perform <math> y_{i+1}^{k+1} = y_i + \Delta x {f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^{(k)}) \over 2}</math> Where k increases by one for each iteration and when the difference between any two iterations is less than the given stopping criterion, epsilon.

==Euler's Method== Euler's method is a numerical method aimed at solving ODE initial value problems.
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math>
==Heun's Method==
For step i=1,2,3... and with an IC given as <math>x(x_0,y_0)</math>
# <math>y_{i+1}^{(0)} = y_i + \Delta xf(x_i,y_i)</math> Note, this step uses Euler's method. # <math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i + \Delta x{f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^{(0)}) \over 2}</math>
Heun's Method can be improved by adding one more step, and by adding a stopping criterion.
# Perform <math> y_{i+1}^{k+1} = y_i + \Delta x {f(x_i,y_i)+f(x_{i+1},y_{i+1}^{(k)}) \over 2}</math> Where k increases by one for each iteration and when the difference between any two iterations is less than the given stopping criterion, epsilon.
==High Order Taylor's Series Methods== The following approximation is called a "Taylor's Series Method of Order n"
<math>y_{i+1} \approx y_i + \Delta xf(x_i,y_i) + {\Delta x^2 \over 2}f'(x_i,y_i) + {\Delta x^3 \over 3!}f''(x_i,y_i) + ... + {\Delta x^n \over n!}f^{(n-1)}(x_i,y_i)</math>
==Solving Systems of ODE's== A system of first order ordinary differential equations can be numerically solved applying the same procedures as in the case of a single differential equation... (just make a system of the methods' equations and solve?)
==Refresher Links== http://www4.ncsu.edu/unity/lockers/users/f/felder/public/kenny/papers/partial.html

revision.comment: Created page with "==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points. ===Procedure=== Given a set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{..."
revision.text:
==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== Given a set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0} and a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}}</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2</math>
<math>a_{1} = n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== ===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== Linear regression was covered in MTE 201 (Statistics) and MTE 204 (Numerical Methods)
===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
===Correlation coefficient=== The correlation coefficient (<math>r</math>) is used to indicate how strong the correlation between the regression line and data points is. r rangers from 0 to 1.0, with 1.0 being a perfect correlation. It is calculated as follows:
<math>r^2 = {S_{0}} - S \over S_{0}}</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== Linear regression was covered in MTE 201 (Statistics) and MTE 204 (Numerical Methods)
===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
===Correlation coefficient=== The correlation coefficient (<math>r</math>) is used to indicate how strong the correlation between the regression line and data points is. r rangers from 0 to 1.0, with 1.0 being a perfect correlation. It is calculated as follows:
<math>r^2 = {S_{0}} - S \over S_{0}}</math>
With:
<math> S = \sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_ix_i)^2}</math>
<math>S_{0} = \sum{(y_{i} - \bar y)^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==

==Linear Regression== Linear regression was covered in MTE 201 (Statistics) and MTE 204 (Numerical Methods)
===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
===Correlation coefficient=== The correlation coefficient (<math>r</math>) is used to indicate how strong the correlation between the regression line and data points is. r rangers from 0 to 1.0, with 1.0 being a perfect correlation. It is calculated as follows:
<math>r^2 = {S_{0}} - S \over S_{0}}</math>
With:
<math> S = \sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_ix_i)^2}</math>
<math>S_{0} = \sum{(y_{i} - \bar y)^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==
===Procedure=== *The general form of the polynomial of best fit is: <math>y = a_0 +a_1x +a_2x^2 + ... + A_mx^m</math>

==Linear Regression== Linear regression was covered in MTE 201 (Statistics) and MTE 204 (Numerical Methods)
===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
===Correlation coefficient=== The correlation coefficient (<math>r</math>) is used to indicate how strong the correlation between the regression line and data points is. r rangers from 0 to 1.0, with 1.0 being a perfect correlation. It is calculated as follows:
<math>r^2 = {S_{0}} - S \over S_{0}}</math>
With:
<math> S = \sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_ix_i)^2}</math>
<math>S_{0} = \sum{(y_{i} - \bar y)^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==
===Procedure=== *The general form of the polynomial of best fit is: <math>y = a_0 +a_1x +a_2x^2 + ... + A_mx^m</math> *The sum of squares of the regression is given by <math>S=\sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_1x_i - a_2x_i^2 - ... - a_mx_i^m)^2 *How do we find the coefficients?!?!

==Linear Regression== Linear regression was covered in MTE 201 (Statistics) and MTE 204 (Numerical Methods)
===Goal=== Linear regression fits the best straight line approximation to a set of data points.
===Procedure=== *A set of data points <math>(x_{1},y_{1}),...,(x_{n},y_{n})</math> should be given *The equation of the regression line is <math>y=a_{0}+a_{1}x</math> where <math>y=a_{0}, a_{1}x</math> are constants we are about to determine. *The error between the line and any given data point <math>(x_{i},y_{i})</math> is given by the equation: <math>e_{i}=y_{i}-a_{0}-a_{1}x_{i}</math> *The coefficients <math>y=a_{0}</math> and <math>a_{1}x</math> are calculated as follows:
<math>a_{0} = {\sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}^2} - \sum{x_{i}}\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
<math>a_{1} = {n\sum{x_{i}y_{i}} - \sum{y_{i}}\sum{x_{i}} \over n\sum{x_{i}^2} - (\sum{x_{i}})^2}</math>
===Correlation coefficient=== The correlation coefficient (<math>r</math>) is used to indicate how strong the correlation between the regression line and data points is. r rangers from 0 to 1.0, with 1.0 being a perfect correlation. It is calculated as follows:
<math>r^2 = {S_{0}} - S \over S_{0}}</math>
With:
<math> S = \sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_ix_i)^2}</math>
<math>S_{0} = \sum{(y_{i} - \bar y)^2</math>
==Polynomial Regression==
===Procedure=== *The general form of the polynomial of best fit is: <math>y = a_0 +a_1x +a_2x^2 + ... + A_mx^m</math> *The sum of squares of the regression is given by <math>S=\sum{(y_i - a_0 - a_1x_i - a_2x_i^2 - ... - a_mx_i^m)^2</math> *How do we find the coefficients?!?!

SYDE 252

==Linear Systems and Signals== Models and analysis of linear systems. Discrete time systems, continuous time systems; difference and differential equations; impulse and frequency response. Complex frequency, functions of complex variables, transform domain techniques: Z transforms; Fourier analysis, Laplace transform. Transfer functions and frequency response, frequency domain analysis of linear systems; sampling theory, stability, and linear filters.
==Important Dates==

revision.comment: Created page with "==Definition== Volume per unit mass. It is the reciprocal of density: <math> v - 1/\rho </math>"
revision.text: ==Definition== Volume per unit mass. It is the reciprocal of density: <math> v - 1/\rho </math>
==Definition== Volume per unit mass. It is the reciprocal of density: <math> v = 1/\rho </math>

revision.comment: Created page with "This philosophy is still being developed, but please have a read of it in its current form. The Twiki aspires to provide a DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) and NBS (No Bullshit) vers..."
revision.text:
This philosophy is still being developed, but please have a read of it in its current form.
The Twiki aspires to provide a DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) and NBS (No Bullshit) version of all the information provided in UW Mechatronics courses, lectures and labs.
The goal at the end of the day is to create a set of notes which provide the information necessary to understand course material and help each student complete their assignments, labs, project and exams. Every bit of information a Tron student learns on their own and says "Damn, I wish they has just ''told'' me that in class" should be present on the twiki.
Bullshit which is not welcome on the Twiki include long, pointless derivations and pointless notes that profs give us saying "you will never need this for this course, or life"... That's all we can really think of for now.
So jump in, and help improve the Twiki.
-The Twiki Contributors (This could be you!)

This philosophy is still being developed, but please have a read of it in its current form.
The Twiki aspires to provide a DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) and NBS (No Bullshit) version of all the information provided in UW Mechatronics courses, lectures and labs. This can be done by linking to pages that already exist instead of re-writing an explanation, and trimming the fat off of professors' course notes.
The goal at the end of the day is to create a set of notes which provide the information necessary to understand course material and help each student complete their assignments, labs, project and exams. Every bit of information a Tron student learns on their own and says "Damn, I wish they has just ''told'' me that in class" should be present on the twiki.
Bullshit which is not welcome on the Twiki include long, pointless derivations and pointless notes that profs give us saying "you will never need this for this course, or life"... That's all we can really think of for now.
So jump in, and help improve the Twiki.
-The Twiki Contributors (This could be you!)

{{Course}}
{{Template:Course}}

==Introduction== WatPD-Engineering is the new replacement for PD-Eng starting the Winter of 2011. It is the result of a year long external review of the PDEng programme and is designed to fix what was widely acknowledged to be a flawed system.
WatPD-Engineering is divided into two mandatory courses and three electives. The mandatory courses have been developped for and are run by WatPD-Engineering. These core courses give students the pre-requisite knowledge for both their coop placements as well as future WatPD electives. The WatPD electives are campus-wide courses that coop students in other faculties have been taking for many years. While electives for engineers are in the works, WatPD-Engineering is focusing on the two core courses and does not expect to develop any core courses in the near future.
__TOC__
==Links==
==Course Notes==
==Important Dates==

==Definitiion==
<math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| \< \infty</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| \lt \infty</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>
==Properties of the Z-transform==
===Right Shift===
A simple case:
More generally:
<math>x[n - m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{-m}}X[z] + z^{-m}\sum_{n=1}^mx[-n]z^n</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>
==Properties of the Z-transform==
===Right Shift (Delay)===
A general equation:
<math>x[n - m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{-m}}X[z] + z^{-m}\sum_{n=1}^mx[-n]z^n</math>
===Left Shift (Advance)===
<math>x[n + m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{m}}X[z] - z^{m}\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}x[-n]z^{-n}</math>
===Convolution===
Similar to the laplace transform, z-transform has the following property: <math> x_1[n]*x_2[n] \Longleftrightarrow X_1[z]X_2[z]</math>

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>
==Properties of the Z-transform==
===Right Shift (Delay)===
A general equation:
<math>x[n - m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{-m}}X[z] + z^{-m}\sum_{n=1}^mx[-n]z^n</math>
===Left Shift (Advance)===
<math>x[n + m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{m}}X[z] - z^{m}\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}x[-n]z^{-n}</math>
===Convolution===
Similar to the laplace transform, z-transform has the following property: <math> x_1[n]*x_2[n] \Longleftrightarrow X_1[z]X_2[z]</math>
.... And there are more (page section 5.2 (p. 445 intl text).

==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>
==Properties of the Z-transform==
===Right Shift (Delay)===
A general equation:
<math>x[n - m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{-m}}X[z] + z^{-m}\sum_{n=1}^mx[-n]z^n</math>
===Left Shift (Advance)===
<math>x[n + m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{m}}X[z] - z^{m}\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}x[-n]z^{-n}</math>
===Convolution===
Similar to the laplace transform, z-transform has the following property: <math> x_1[n]*x_2[n] \Longleftrightarrow X_1[z]X_2[z]</math>
.... And there are more (page section 5.2 (p. 445 intl text).
==Frequency Response of a DT System==
System response based on input:
<math> e^(j\Omega n} \arrow H[e^(j\Omega}]e^(j\Omega n} </math>

revision.comment: /* Frequency Response of a DT System */
revision.text:
==Definitiion==
The unilateral Z-transform is defined as: <math>X[z] = {\sum_{n=0}^\infty x[n]z^{-n}</math>
==Existence of the Z-transform==
The existence of the z-transform of a function is guaranteed if : <math>|X[z]| < \infty</math>
==Properties of the Z-transform==
===Right Shift (Delay)===
A general equation:
<math>x[n - m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{-m}}X[z] + z^{-m}\sum_{n=1}^mx[-n]z^n</math>
===Left Shift (Advance)===
<math>x[n + m]u[n] \Longleftrightarrow {z^{m}}X[z] - z^{m}\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}x[-n]z^{-n}</math>
===Convolution===
Similar to the laplace transform, z-transform has the following property: <math> x_1[n]*x_2[n] \Longleftrightarrow X_1[z]X_2[z]</math>
.... And there are more (page section 5.2 (p. 445 intl text).
==Frequency Response of a DT System==
System response based on input:
<math> Input: e^{j \Omega n} \to Response: H[e^{j \Omega}]e^{j \Omega n} </math>
<math> Input: cos (\Omega n) \to Response: |H[e^{j \Omega}]|cos(\Omega n + \angle H[e^{j \Omega}]) </math>
